text:
Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts about where you are. The website's message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are also telling everyone, including people you might not want to meet. This made people realize that sharing everything online might not always be good. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with the world, which can be exciting. We share our secrets, photos, and stories online. But sometimes, we find out too late that it can be risky and confusing.

This might sound sad, but don't worry. There is a way to understand this future, thanks to some early internet users. In the early days of the web, these people explored the internet and faced many challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with fame before social media existed. These early users, known as bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through now. We can learn from their stories.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," which was mostly used by students and scientists. The web was created at Cern, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. But Hall saw it as a way to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were interested in his bold use of this new medium. Hall shared everything, and nothing was off-limits. His work was very open, but it was also artistic.

One day, visitors to Hall’s site found it replaced with a video called Dark Night. He had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped the blog, but the problem of sharing too much online remains. Sharing online is fun, but if you think it will make people like you more, you might be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company’s vice presidents, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. This is an example of the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online they wouldn’t say in person. But the internet is not a place where we can say anything without consequences. Our online and real lives are connected, and pretending otherwise can lead to big mistakes.

Armstrong’s story ended well. She was upset and stopped blogging for a while, but she got married and started blogging again about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned that just because we can say anything online, it doesn’t mean we should.

Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe that we don't understand. Most scientists agree that we don't know everything about the universe. However, some scientists were worried about the film and called it things like "atrocious" and "very dangerous." This made the film seem interesting to watch.

At first, the film seemed harmless. Scientists in the film talked about how new discoveries show that the universe is stranger than we thought. But then the film talked about discoveries like water molecules being affected by thoughts. A Japanese researcher claimed that the shape of water molecules could change just by the thoughts of people around them. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by someone happy and looking bad after being exposed to someone in a bad mood. Some people found this evidence convincing, but many scientists did not. They wanted more proof that this effect was real, not just pretty pictures.

The film's claims were not strange enough. For example, water molecules might have properties due to a form of energy that comes from nowhere and is linked to a force expanding the universe. This idea is supported by years of research. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is pushed by a mysterious force called "dark energy." Other discoveries are also amazing. Neuroscientists found that our brain's perception of events is delayed by about half a second. Anthropologists think they know where modern humans came from and why they spread across the world. Some theorists believe there are links between life on Earth and the universe's design.

Science is not finished. We are further from knowing everything than ever before. Concepts like chaos and quantum uncertainty show that we can't understand everything completely. Some physicists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all forces and particles in the universe with one equation. Despite these theories, many people think the universe is best described with one word: incredible.

Writing novels and short stories is different for me. Writing novels is hard, like planting a forest, while writing short stories is fun, like planting a garden. Both are important and make a complete picture that I love. Trees in the forest give shade, and the garden has flowers that attract bees and butterflies. Since I started writing, I switch between novels and short stories. After finishing a novel, I write short stories, and after short stories, I go back to novels. I never mix the two because they use different parts of my brain. 

I began my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I started writing short stories. It was hard at first, but I enjoyed it and felt my writing world grow. Readers liked this new side of me. One of my first stories, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. Writing short stories is nice because they don’t take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to make a short story good, though I might revise it many times. Writing a novel takes a year or two and is a big commitment. Short stories are a nice change for me.

Short stories can come from small ideas, like a word or an image. It’s like jazz, where the story leads me. If a story doesn’t work, it’s okay. Not every story is a masterpiece, even for great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. I learn from my mistakes and use that in my next story. Writing short stories helps me when I write novels. They are like experiments for me. Without them, writing novels would be harder. My short stories are like soft shadows or footprints I leave behind. I remember each one and how I felt when I wrote it. They are like signs to my heart, and I’m happy to share these feelings with my readers.

Science can be very abstract, like philosophy, or very practical, like curing diseases. It has made our lives easier but also brought dangers. Science tries to understand everything from tiny atoms to the vast universe, but it doesn't always succeed. It influences poets, politicians, and thinkers. Its beauty is often seen only by experts, and its dangers are often misunderstood. People sometimes think science is more or less important than it really is, and they often ignore its mistakes.

Science is full of conflicts. Old ideas are often changed or replaced by new ones. Like in music, new ideas in science are sometimes laughed at but later become accepted. Scientists can be jealous and angry, and the history of science is full of struggles. This book talks about scientific ideas that changed not just science but also human thought. We will focus on these ideas, not on practical things like non-stick frying pans. We will admire the beauty of these ideas but also question them, knowing that human understanding has limits.

Science is always changing. Scientists often prove each other wrong. Usually, these changes don't affect society much, but sometimes they cause big shifts in our beliefs. In the 17th century, science described the universe as a giant clock. Three centuries later, physics showed that our observations can affect the universe, and we don't fully understand our basic concepts. Some people think this shows science can't explain everything, but scientific changes usually help us understand and predict nature better. Isaac Newton explained more than Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained more than Newton. Science makes mistakes but keeps moving forward.

At the end of the 19th century, many physicists thought there was nothing new to discover. Then came radioactivity, X-rays, electrons, quantum mechanics, and more. Biology has also made many discoveries. Some people now say we are close to a complete theory of everything. Maybe. Science is not just a hobby. In the last two centuries, we have started to control nature, sometimes upsetting its balance. We need to watch science carefully. Everyone should understand scientific advances because they affect our world and future generations. Science is now part of how we plan our future, and these decisions are important for budgets, health, and life on Earth.

Since around 2015, big publishers noticed that ebook sales stopped growing or even went down. This made people question if ebooks have a strong future in the publishing world. One publishing executive said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments, as his company lost faith in traditional books. Even though digital and print books can exist together, people still wonder if ebooks will replace print books. This idea keeps our imagination active and sparks debates. Why do we think of ebooks and print books as being in a fight, even when evidence shows they can coexist? This question is not just about ebooks; it shows how we feel both excited and scared about new technology and change.

In my research, I found that whenever a new technology comes out, people often think it will replace the old one. For example, when television was invented, many thought radio would disappear. But radio survived by finding new uses, like being listened to in cars or at work. The idea of books disappearing is not new either. In 1894, people thought the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This pattern has happened many times. Movies, radio, television, and smartphones have all been seen as threats to print books. Some people thought losing books would harm culture, while others believed ebooks would bring great benefits.

The idea of books disappearing often comes up during times of technological change. This story shows our mixed feelings about new technology. We form emotional connections with things like books, TVs, and computers because they are important in our lives. Studies show we even name our cars or get mad at our laptops when they don't work. So, when new technology like e-readers appears, it changes our relationship with things we are used to. As technology changes, we miss what we used to have, which is why industries for old products and technologies exist. For example, when the printing press spread in 15th-century Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. When movies added sound in the 1920s, people felt nostalgic for silent films. The same happened with the change from analog to digital photography and from vinyl records to CDs. E-readers made people appreciate the feel and smell of old books again.

This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of a disappearing medium will continue to be a popular story about the power of technology and our dislike of change. We use familiar stories, like those of tragedy and endings, to understand change. The story of the death of the book reflects our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our familiar world and ourselves.

For almost every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and sat down to write. I wrote about how some of the greatest minds in the past 400 years found time each day to do their best work. I looked at how they organized their schedules to be creative and productive. By writing about the simple details of their daily lives—like when they slept, ate, and worked—I wanted to show a new side of their personalities and careers. I wanted to show that they were like us, with habits and routines. 

The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, "Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are." I say, "Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward." This book is about the circumstances of creative work, not the work itself. It’s about how things are made, not what they mean. But it’s also personal. The novelist John Cheever said you can’t even type a business letter without showing something of your inner self. My book looks at questions I struggle with: How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to focus completely on a project or to work on it a little each day? When there isn’t enough time for everything, do you have to give things up, or can you learn to do more in less time?

I don’t have all the answers, but I’ve tried to show how different successful people have faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas come from small daily actions and how working habits affect the work itself. The book is called Daily Rituals, but it’s really about people’s routines. A routine can seem ordinary, but it can also be a way to use limited resources like time, willpower, and optimism. A good routine helps focus your mental energy and keeps you from being controlled by your moods. The psychologist William James thought you should put part of your life on autopilot. By forming good habits, he said, we can focus on more interesting things. Ironically, James himself was a procrastinator and couldn’t stick to a schedule.

This book started from my own procrastination. One Sunday, I was at work trying to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I was tidying my desk and making coffee. I’m a morning person, good at focusing early in the day but not after lunch. To feel better, I started looking online for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories and thought someone should collect them. So, I started the Daily Routines blog that afternoon, and now, this book. The blog was simple; I posted descriptions of people’s routines from biographies, magazine profiles, and newspaper obituaries. For the book, I expanded and researched more, keeping the short and varied voices that made the blog popular. I let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. This book wouldn’t be possible without the work of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which can also guide further reading.

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, decided they couldn't go on a holiday to Spain because of high interest rates. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach, and this sparked his interest in becoming a palaeontologist. 

As he studied at university, Howard realized he was interested in the very early history of life, not in dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. He liked studying ancient, delicate creatures found in rocks. When he finished his doctoral thesis, he worried about finding a job. He knew he was talented, but getting a job in science can be difficult.

Howard applied for a job at Tavistock College in London. On the day of his interview, the professor who was supposed to support another candidate couldn't attend because of an accident. The replacement professor didn't like the absent professor and made sure Howard got the job instead. Howard was surprised but happy to get the job, even after he learned why he was chosen. 

Howard enjoyed his work, which was organized and planned, unlike the unpredictable events in life. One day, his briefcase with important lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. Annoyed, he went back to the college and postponed his lecture. While having coffee with a colleague and a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi, he learned about a new collection of fossils that needed study. This opportunity became his biggest challenge and secured his future. 

Because of the theft, Howard changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students on a trip to Scotland. Instead, he focused on finding the money to visit the museum in Nairobi. 

*An ammonite is a type of fossil from an extinct group of marine mollusk animals.

Charles Spence is a professor at Oxford University who studies how our senses work together to create the taste of food. He is interested in making unusual foods, like ice cream made from bee larvae, more acceptable to people. Spence's research, called "gastro physics," looks at how different things affect our eating experience, such as who we eat with, how food is presented, and even the sounds we hear while eating.

Spence has written a book called "The Perfect Meal" with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, which shares interesting facts about eating. For example, the first person to order in a restaurant usually enjoys their meal the most, and we eat more when dining with others.

His lab at Oxford is simple and not high-tech, which allows him to work creatively with chefs who can't afford their own research. Much of his work is funded by big food companies. These companies are interested in reducing salt and sugar in their products without customers noticing, as it helps keep their customers healthy.

Spence has also worked with famous chef Heston Blumenthal to create dishes that combine food and sound, like the "Sound of the Sea" dish. His research shows that music can change how we taste food, with high-pitched music making food taste sweeter and low-pitched sounds making it taste bitter.

Spence's work is being used by the food industry in many ways. For example, an airline plans to match music with the food served to passengers. At home, Spence experiments with different sensory experiences during dinner parties, like using colored lights and sound to see how they affect taste. For Spence, both his home and his lab are places to explore how we experience food.

Our brains are busier than ever. We get a lot of information, some true and some not, and we have to decide what is important. We also do more things ourselves now. For example, we book our own flights and find things in shops without help. We try to manage our lives, families, jobs, hobbies, and TV shows, often using our smartphones to help. But there is a problem. We think we can do many things at once, but this is not true. Earl Miller, a scientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly between tasks, which is not efficient. This can make us stressed and confused. Multitasking can also make us want more distractions. Our brain likes new things, so it is easily distracted. Just having the chance to multitask can make us perform worse. Glenn Wilson, a psychology professor, found that trying to focus on a task while having an unread email can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. This is worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, a scientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework and watch TV, the information goes to a part of the brain for skills, not facts. Without TV, it goes to a part where it is better organized. Multitasking also involves making decisions, which is hard for our brains. Even small decisions can use a lot of brain power, leading to bad decisions later. Many people, including business leaders and scientists, say email is a big problem. It is not the email itself, but the large amount of communication. One scientist's son said his dad's job is answering emails, which is almost true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do that and finish other tasks.

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions were not important. Scientists only looked at animal behaviors and their results. They did not think animals had feelings or morals. But now, this is changing. Research on animals like bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens shows that animals might have emotions. This change has led to books like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". These books have started a debate: do animals have consciousness? This leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong? 

In one experiment, cows had to open a gate to get food. Cows that opened the gate themselves were happier than those that needed help. If cows like solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? Some people, like Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, think we should stop eating meat. He believes this is a big change in ethics, like when slavery ended. Aubrey Manning, a professor, thinks we should rethink how we see animal intelligence. He believes animals have a simpler mind than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop giving animals human traits. 

These views may never agree because the main issue is philosophical. It is hard to define consciousness, so can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment with starlings, a type of bird. At Newcastle University, starlings were put in two groups. One group had nice cages, and the other had small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box. Later, when only bad worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt pessimistic. Balcombe, who supports animal rights, believes our view on animals will change, like our view on racism. He says we cannot support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger. If he were alone in this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees with him. Manning wrote a textbook on animal behavior. He says opinions on animal thinking have changed over time. It is a difficult topic, and people have strong opinions.

Critical thinking is a way of understanding what we read or hear more deeply. Adrian West, from the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., says that people often think arguments help find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might also change how we solve problems and make it harder to think deeply. West mentions that we are surrounded by a lot of poor but attractive ideas and opinions, which can confuse our thinking. More information does not always mean better knowledge or decisions. 

Reading books has decreased, and some experts, like Patricia Greenfield, believe that focusing more on visual media, like TV and video games, might reduce critical thinking. She says that reading helps imagination and thinking in ways that visual media do not. However, visual media can improve some types of information processing. Most visual media do not give time for thinking or imagination, which might lead to people not using their full potential.

The way society views technology affects how we think about critical thinking. Video games are a good example. Some people think they are bad for kids, but James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, says they can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills. They allow players to explore ideas in a virtual world similar to the real one. As reading and math scores go down, it is important to understand how technology affects our thinking.

Matthew Crawford is a writer and motorcycle mechanic. He used to work in an office but left because he didn't like it. His first book talks about the benefits of working with your hands. His latest book is about dealing with modern life. He got the idea for this book when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. Crawford noticed that these ads make it hard for us to focus on what we want to think about. We often don't realize how much they affect us. This makes it difficult to think or remember past conversations. To avoid being interrupted, people stop talking to strangers. Crawford says we often see the world through things like video games and phone apps, which can control our desires. Many people are worried about this. For example, some office workers complain about emails but still check them in their free time. Studies show that just seeing a phone on a table can distract us. There is no proof yet that our attention spans are shorter, but we are more aware of other things we could be doing. Crawford believes technology makes it easy for us to focus on ourselves. This affects our self-control and social life. We prefer texting to talking because it's easier. By only interacting with screens, we might lose important social skills. Crawford gives an example from his gym. Before, there was one music player for everyone, which sometimes caused disagreements. Now, people use earbuds and listen to their own music, making the gym less social. Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we should have rules to reduce noise and distractions in public. Second, we should do activities that require skill, like cooking or playing sports, to connect with the real world. These activities help us focus better and make us less distracted by technology.

Text: "‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often define ourselves by our jobs. For most people, it's easy to answer. But for me, as a philosopher, it's a bit harder. Saying you are a philosopher can sound a bit arrogant. People might think you claim to know some special truth. This is not true; philosophers are just like everyone else. But this idea makes me pause. Why do people think this way about philosophers? One reason is that philosophers are seen as people who think deeply and value intellectual life. The Greek philosopher Aristotle said that a life of thinking is the best life. Not many modern philosophers agree, but philosophy is still linked to deep thinking. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said, ‘the unexamined life is not worth living’. He meant that just following what everyone else does is not satisfying. We can think about our lives and make our own choices. But you don't need to read a lot of philosophy books to do this. It just means looking closely at our daily lives to see if they are really important. You don't have to be a wise person living away from society. In fact, thinking about life should be practical and shared with others. This is part of a good life. Another reason people misunderstand philosophers is that academic philosophy has become very separate from everyday life. This is partly because of how universities work. Philosophers often write in expensive and hard-to-read journals. So, they don't get to share their ideas with many people. For most people, philosophy seems far from real life. If philosophers used to fight this idea, many don't anymore. Universities have created a place where philosophers are isolated, and they have supported this. Some areas of philosophy are now very technical and hard to understand, even for other philosophers. Philosophy has, in some cases, moved away from society. This needs to change. I sometimes call myself an ‘ethicist’ because I work in ethics, which is about judging human actions. But I feel this title doesn't fully explain my work. Ethics is often seen as rules and laws. This is a new idea in philosophy. Ethics now often means applied ethics, which looks at whether certain social practices are fair. Ethicists today decide if something is ‘ethical’ or okay. These are important questions, and I think about them a lot. But philosophy is more than this. A discussion might start with whether downloading films illegally is wrong (it is) and then look at how we think about responsibility, art, and consumerism. Philosophy helps us look closely at our actions and beliefs. Sometimes we find out things we already know; other times, we see our beliefs are hard to defend. By thinking about these ideas, we help everyone."

Text: People who love food, like foodies, chefs, and gourmands, might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. In the past, philosophers talked about food mainly to discuss other ideas. When they mentioned eating, it was often a metaphor for learning or understanding something else. Sometimes, it seemed like they were talking about food, but they were actually discussing deeper topics. 

An interesting example is the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus. He believed in seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in many parts of life. However, his name is now often linked with a love for eating and drinking. We see his name used in restaurants, food shops, and recipe websites. These businesses likely hope that using his name will make their products more appealing.

Food is a social and cultural thing. It comes from history and is shared with people in our communities. These communities give us people to eat with and help grow and distribute food. We interact with food more often and in more important ways than with any other product, making it a good topic for philosophical discussion.

Once food is made, critics talk and write about it. But why do they have such an important role? One philosopher says that tasting food is not a special skill. Instead, food critics are just better at describing tastes. Philosophers have not paid much attention to how we taste, focusing more on vision. This should change.

Another part of food is aesthetics, or beauty. We often say paintings or music are beautiful, but not food. Some philosophers think that with modern cooking, food should be part of discussions about beauty, like art or poetry. But food is eaten and disappears, unlike art or music, which lasts over time. So, some think food cannot be considered a true object of beauty.

There are many ethical questions about food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? Our choices often show our ethical beliefs. Philosophers ask why we make these choices, and discussing this is important.

Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a special duty to their guests because of love and friendship. At home, everyone shares food and companionship. Professional cooks have responsibilities to their employers and the food. Their kitchens are for qualified people, and their relationships are professional.

A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ looks at how food can help bridge cultural gaps. This happens in two ways. First, we can appreciate other cultures by enjoying their food. Second, we build personal connections with people from other cultures by eating together, a practice with a long history in diplomacy. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories, making this part of food philosophy exciting for readers.

Rob Daviau, from the US, creates 'legacy' board games. He thought the board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. So, he started thinking about how board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices made in one game affect the next one? He changed a classic board game called Risk to make a new version: Risk Legacy. In this game, choices made during play have a lasting effect. Players might have to tear up cards, write on the board, or open packets with new rules. The game is played over several sessions, and players remember past actions. Daviau said: ‘You could point to the board and say: “Right here! You did this!”’

Daviau was then asked to help make a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players work together to stop diseases. His next project was a game called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very popular, SeaFall was a big test for the legacy format because it was not based on an earlier game. Set in the age of sail (16th – mid 19th century), players explore and conquer new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all possible player choices to keep the story together. They use testers to see how the game will play out. Jaime Barriga, a tester for SeaFall, said: ‘It takes a lot of time. Sometimes the first few games are great, but then it starts to have problems, and you have to fix everything.’

Legacy board games were not expected to become very popular. Even Daviau thought it would be a small interest. ‘When I was working on it, I thought: “This is different and good,”’ he said. ‘But it’s strange and breaks many rules. I thought only a few people would like it.’ However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He thinks it is a big step forward in game design. ‘It’s a new level of excitement,’ he said. ‘There’s nothing more exciting for a board gamer than learning a new game or way to play, and you get that with legacy games.’

Another fan, Ben Hogg, liked the adventure of legacy games more than worrying about the game lasting. ‘At first, I was worried about changing and ruining the board,’ he said. ‘But Pandemic Legacy changed that. Most people don’t watch the same movie twice, do they? You’re buying an experience. It’s like the stories in video games.’ The legacy format is similar to video games and popular TV series. Daviau wanted to be a TV writer in college but moved to advertising and then game design. He still liked telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compares making a legacy game to writing a book. ‘You need to know how it starts and ends,’ he said. ‘But you also need more than just an outline.’

While Daviau feels proud of his work, he wants to see what others do with the idea. But he also thinks people will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, from the publisher of SeaFall, thinks the legacy format is a big change. ‘It changes how you think about what a board game can be,’ he said.

One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and squeezed into a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online and seemed like something from a children's movie. People enjoy stories like this because they like to imagine animals acting like humans. This is especially true for octopuses, which are very smart even though they look very different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells as armor, and even play in complex ways.

Some people think that giving animals human-like traits is unscientific. However, Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, believes that ignoring the human-like traits of animals is the real problem. He calls this "anthropodenial." He says that animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others' motives. Animals are smarter than we often think.

In the past, people believed animals were smart. In medieval Europe, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. In the 19th century, scientists like Charles Darwin thought that the difference between humans and animals was not very big. But in the 20th century, people started to see animals as simple creatures that only responded to rewards and punishments. This view changed how people treated animals and their habitats.

Dr. de Waal believes we are now starting to understand animal intelligence better. He says that the best tests for animal intelligence consider the unique skills of each species. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hid their nuts. In her book, "The Soul of an Octopus," Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might think we are not very smart because we can't change the color of our skin.

Dr. de Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean, but he knows that stories like Inky's help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment with capuchin monkeys to see if they could feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers got upset. A video of this experiment convinced many people of the findings. This shows how powerful stories and videos can be in changing our views on animal intelligence.

Text: 'Robotics, once only seen in science fiction, is now becoming a major change in technology, similar to the industrial revolution. Robots have been used in car and factory work for many years, but experts say robots will soon be used in many more areas. However, many countries are not ready for this big change. Most people think robots will do most jobs in the next 50 years, but they also believe their own jobs will still exist. This is not true: all job areas will be affected by robots soon. For example, an Australian company, Fastbrick Robotics, made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour, a job that takes two people almost a day. In San Francisco, a company called Simbe Robotics created Tally, a robot that moves around supermarkets to check if products are stocked and priced correctly. People who support robots say they will create new jobs for skilled workers like technicians and programmers. But critics say we should not forget the importance of human skills at work. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots are changing jobs. His research shows that soon, many robots will be smarter and able to work with humans. In a few years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will make new laws about robots. In five years, salaries in robotics will go up by 60%, but many jobs will still be empty because there are not enough skilled workers. Zhang says that people with lower skills will be affected by robots, and they should learn new skills instead of hoping the government will protect their jobs. New technologies will also create new types of robots for homes and personal use, like robots that can walk and interact with us. This is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. With many jobs at risk, education is important to prepare for the future. Countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM) to stay competitive.'

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, once answered a reporter's question about why he wanted to climb Mount Everest by saying, "Because it's there." The reporter's question showed that many people want to understand why someone would do something so dangerous. Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams and face the unknown. The real reason for climbing might just be adventure and fun.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called ‘Games that Climbers Play’. He described seven different types of climbing activities, each with its own rules. He said that the way you climb, like using more or less equipment, depends on the rules of the game you are playing. Over the years, this idea has become very popular in the climbing world, influencing everything from magazines to discussions around campfires.

Many climbers love climbing because it makes them feel free. However, climbing can also be limiting, like when you are stuck in a tent during a storm. This shows a paradox: climbing can feel both freeing and restricting. But some say that having fewer choices makes life simpler, which is a kind of freedom.

US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He thinks climbing is in our genes and that we naturally want to take on challenges, even if they are risky. This means the joy of climbing is more about biology than logic.

US academic Brian Treanor wrote that climbing helps develop important virtues like courage, humility, and respect for nature. He believes these virtues are important in today's world, which often avoids risks. Climbing can help people develop traits that are useful in everyday life.

Some climbers believe that those who climb without help from others or technology must be very committed to succeed. Experts Ebert and Robinson argued that climbing is more impressive when done independently, without things like bottled oxygen. This idea caused some controversy because it might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.

Climbing can also be understood by looking beyond Western ideas. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "in the zone" while climbing. The physical effort, meditation, and problem-solving involved in climbing are similar to techniques in Zen philosophy, which aims for a state of perfect peace. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became very important in classical music. He was a serious and smart person who played and recorded many famous European piano pieces. He wrote and played a lot but did not teach much. People who knew him well saw he could be fun, but he was usually serious in his concerts. His life was full of study, travel, and performances. 

Then, a few years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not think it was a good idea. He had not taught many students and did not plan to start. He said, ‘You don’t need a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ But there was something special about Kit, who was about 14 years old then. Brendel listened to him play and was impressed. Kit played very well from memory and gave Brendel a CD of a recital he had done. Brendel thought, “I have to make time for him.” Kit’s performance was very special, and it is rare to find a musician with such skill.

As Brendel is retiring, Kit is starting his career, but Brendel is careful to make sure Kit does not work too hard too soon. Kit, now 19, is always busy learning new things like languages, math, computer coding, and playing tennis, with his mother always watching over him. He also writes music. Brendel says this is important because writing music helps you understand it better. Kit has a great memory and can read music very well. He listens carefully to his own playing and to Brendel’s advice. When Brendel explains something, Kit understands and can do it.

Brendel is careful not to raise too many expectations. He does not like it when newspapers call Kit the future great pianist of the 21st century because it can be harmful. Kit can play some things very well, but he still needs time and experience for others. Critics should not expect him to be perfect.

Now, at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed. He says, ‘When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by the age of 50. When I reached 50, I had done most of those things, but I continued to do more. Even though I don’t have the physical strength now, I still think about many pieces I’ve never played. I don’t play now, but it’s a nice new part of my life.’

When I was a child, I thought gardens were always beautiful places. My Grandad's garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went down gently to the water. You couldn't reach the river, but you could hear the water and birds singing in the trees. I believed all gardens were like this – places to escape, find peace, and be alone. Grandad's garden was simple. He didn't have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic covering broken glass.

At home, my father was often quiet. He wasn't without humor, though. He liked to say things like, "It's immaterial to me," instead of just saying, "I don't mind." He probably wished he had done more with his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber, but he didn't love it. He wasn't very ambitious, though he and my mom once thought about moving to Canada, but it didn't happen. He was good at fixing things around the house, like making bookshelves or cupboards.

My parents only moved house once, but my mom liked to change the furniture often. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when we got a piano. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mom thought they were too fancy and took them away. I never got to play the piano; my sister had lessons instead. When I asked my mom later why I didn't get lessons, she said, "You'd never have practiced."

I liked going to the river more than the moors or woods. I would go there with a fishing net and old sandals. I would find a spot to take off my sandals and look for fish to catch with my net. After trying to keep them alive at home, I would put them back in the river.

I wanted to leave school as soon as I could, but it seemed unlikely until my father said, "There's a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested." My dad usually didn't like gardening, but he saw how much I loved it. I like to think he hoped it would be a good choice for me.

Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck, and I am with him. The strong wind from the Atlantic feels like it could blow us off the cliff and into the ocean below. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, comes over, and MacEwen gently pets him. Even with the wind, MacEwen looks comfortable on his island. He points to the north and shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.’ I see rain falling on Rum's big mountains. ‘Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.’ When rain starts coming our way, MacEwen says, ‘I have sheep to move.’ We walk down the slopes, and he tells me about the island: Muck is three km long and half as wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwens have lived here for 3000 years. We stop talking to herd the sheep. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to gather the sheep but is not doing well. ‘Away to me, Tie. Away to me,’ MacEwen says, meaning the dog should go to the right. But Tie goes straight into the flock, causing confusion. ‘Tie,’ MacEwen says, sounding disappointed. ‘That will never do.’ The dog looks sorry. The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence runs the farm with his wife, Jenny; their son Colin, who is newly married, manages the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. ‘They go out and come back only when they’re hungry.’ But living on the island has its challenges. For example, electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I see Mary preparing breakfast with a flashlight. I get used to it, along with no mobile phone service. ‘There is mobile reception on the hill,’ Mary tells me. ‘Most people last a couple of days, then just put the phone in the drawer.’ So I do too. Everything on Muck feels surprising. The boat today brings groceries and three musicians with instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with everyone tapping their boots to the music. That night, sitting by a warm fire while it rains outside, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. ‘Her father bought a small farm on the isle of Soay from a newspaper ad without seeing it. He’d never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.’ Did Jenny know how to run a farm? ‘She had good typing skills.’ I go to bed with rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, with almost all the food coming from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I bring it back to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it tastes amazing. Also amazing: my ferry ride the next morning to another island. In the last two months, many ferries were canceled because of high seas. If my ferry didn’t come, I’d be stuck on Muck for two more days. Which, now, with or without a phone, is what I secretly hoped for.

The game design industry used to be mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It was often seen as just a hobby for young people. But now, the video games industry is taken seriously. This doesn't surprise experts. Making video games is not easy. When a new movie comes out, video games based on it need many team members and months of hard work. Like many industries, it's hard to get into, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, who works for an online games magazine, says it’s hard to make progress in big companies or to influence big games. But the industry needs more game designers. Not just the directors who lead the whole game, but also the people who design parts of the game.

How can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim thinks differently. He says the only way is to make games. The tools are available. You need to create something to get a job. Game design is more than a job; it’s a way of life. Like any creative work, you have to do it to make it real.

Another expert, John Field, says there are other ways. He agrees with "just doing it," but says it’s more complicated. Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s needs. Even fewer have the creative talent, technical skills, vision, and business ability to really help the industry grow. Can you do it alone? John says it’s tricky, but a good postgraduate course in games can help. It can give you support and guidance. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all kinds of entertainment and arts. They might have worked for a few years after graduation and then decided that games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and know about the growing variety of games. Connections can also help. Networking is important to get ahead in games, just like in many other fields.

The old idea of a teenage boy playing video games all day is outdated. Now, games are seen as a serious medium. Families often play together on interactive consoles. Smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. Games are popular with large audiences and are a great way to learn. He sees many possibilities and opportunities in this already big area.

Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I'm thankful for that. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy. He always told him what he couldn't do. My friend could have been a good player, but he stopped wanting to play and never played football again. I'm glad that didn't happen to me, but I know it could have been different. When I score a great goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but it's not. I have practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. You can only score amazing goals by practicing a lot. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning skills. I used to play every sport at school, like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know now that education is important, but back then, I only thought about football. The teachers were good, but I didn't notice it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books, even though he's too young to sit still. I hope he doesn't just want to kick them around like I did. At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so young players like me could play for the first team. He didn't make a big deal about it, but we knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A TV presenter said, 'You can't win anything with kids.' That made us realize how much we had to do. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team. I rely on my close friends and family a lot. Having a lot of money can cause problems. People sometimes say, 'I can't believe you let your mother keep working.' I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and they would be upset if they thought they should be on my payroll. My mum doesn't earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. I like using my money to help people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think, and it doesn't solve everything. After I stop playing, I want to take a year off or maybe longer to do things I couldn't do before. I want to go skiing right after I stop playing. I can't do that now because if I broke my leg skiing and couldn't play football, I wouldn't be insured.

Sam Carter was the reason we were living at Reef Point. He was my dad's agent in Los Angeles. My dad couldn't write anything good while we lived in Los Angeles, so Sam offered to find us a cheap place to live. He was worried about losing clients and money. During the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs covered the sun. Reef Point wasn't popular with day-trippers. The road was not nice, and the nearby resort, La Carmella, was more attractive. People only came to Reef Point if they had no money or loved surfing. But when the weather got hot, many people came, and the place was busy. My dad was trying hard to write a script on time and was in a bad mood. I spent most days on the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. We didn't have a dog when we moved to Reef Point, but Rusty decided to stay with us. I tried to chase him away, but he kept coming back. One day, I gave him water, and my dad half-heartedly tried to scare him off. I asked my dad who Rusty belonged to, and he said, "He thinks we belong to him." Rusty loved the beach and often brought me things he found, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, which I had to return to their owners. He also loved swimming and always came with me, even though I was faster. He never got discouraged. That day, my dad went to Los Angeles to deliver his script, and Rusty and I spent the afternoon swimming. As the sun set, we watched the surfers. One surfer stood out to me. She was very skilled. She finished surfing and came over to talk. She asked why I didn't join them, and I said I didn't have a surfboard or money. She noticed I was British and asked if I was visiting. I told her I lived there and that my dad was writing a film script. She asked if she knew him, and I said his name was Rufus Marsh. She recognized his book, "Tall as the Morning," and looked at me with new interest. I realized people were friendly but only really interested when I mentioned my dad's book.

Violet Hetherington was standing in a long line at the dock in Southampton, waiting to board the Queen Caroline ship. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late to avoid waiting, but this advice turned out to be wrong. An announcement said there was a problem with the computer system, making the passengers frustrated. They had paid a lot for this trip and expected better service.

Violet felt like leaving, especially when she realized she had lost her phone. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left it there because all her contacts were saved on the phone. Her son Harry always warned her about this. She asked a friendly couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message asking him to ask her neighbor Kristina to look for her phone at home. If it wasn't there, she would have trouble finding important numbers in New York.

Finally, the line started moving, and Violet handed over her travel documents to board the ship. She was disappointed by the ship's foyer, which looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy. There were fake walnut panels, shiny chandeliers, and airport-style carpets. She took the elevator, crowded with tired passengers, to the twelfth floor where her room was. Thankfully, it had the balcony she wanted. She had paid extra to make sure she could see the sea, ignoring Annie's advice to wait for a last-minute deal.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he didn't know he was about to discover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer with a talent for taking interesting photos. Since then, Maloof has collected many of Maier’s belongings, including her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, as well as 8mm movies and audiotapes. Maloof feels lucky to have found this collection. He said, ‘When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was. I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily just sold it all to someone else.’

Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was known to be private and always had a camera with her. She wore large coats, big hats, and strong shoes. Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier to care for his daughter, said, ‘First thing in the morning on her day off, the camera would be around her neck, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night.’ Maier had strong opinions about movies and politics and knew a lot about theatre and movies. She was not very social but was not afraid to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, sometimes recording them on audiotape. She was very dedicated to her photography, which was like her ‘second job’. Rydzon said, ‘She was a true artist and followed her dreams and what she wanted to do in life. She didn’t let anyone or anything stop her.’

Maier’s work is pure art; she didn’t do it for money. Her photos often show women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. Photography expert Larry Silverman finds her pictures very interesting and wonders if she developed her style on her own or was influenced by other photographers. Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever finish looking through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. Before discovering Maier’s work, Maloof wasn’t very interested in photography. But her photos inspired him to start taking his own pictures. He said, ‘As I progressed as a photographer and went back and visited her work, I realized the cityscapes were not what was important to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, the overall composition.’ Maloof now wants to make sure people know about Vivian Maier and her work. He hopes to get her name into the history books.

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But that's not true for Eleanor Catton's book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular, but she was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her novel to the officer, who asked, "What's it about?" This is a hard question for an author. The Luminaries takes place in the 1860s in New Zealand. There are a series of crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past gave more chances for her characters to face problems. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I asked how it feels to be successful at a young age, she said it's nice coming from a small country because everyone feels part of the success. She added that it bothers her when people think her book isn't a serious work. She had an idea to write the book like a spiral, with each part half the length of the one before. It gets faster as it goes. I asked if it matters if readers notice this. She said she wanted to create a book with patterns that didn't matter, but if readers cared, they could find them. Even with its unusual structure, The Luminaries is an exciting murder mystery with a gripping story. Surprisingly, she didn't plan the story in advance. She would write herself into a difficult situation and then find a creative way out. She also wanted the book to be fun for readers. We talked about her love for TV drama series. I asked if she might want to write for TV. She said, "That could be pretty cool," with excitement. She loves talking about her work and New Zealand. She notices how her imagination changes when she visits Britain. She understands why writers leave New Zealand for busy places to be around more people. But for now, New Zealand will stay her home. Many hope it inspires her to write more novels.

When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he loved making things in his dad’s garage and playing the guitar. These two hobbies became his job for the last forty years: he builds steel-string, acoustic guitars by hand. Jonny says, ‘I’m still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood make such a beautiful sound? And using different types of wood makes different sounds. It still surprises me.’

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar at eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to play the bass guitar. ‘Some people would get a job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I thought if you want something, you make it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and woods change the sound and how to build them.’ The bass was the first instrument Jonny made from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making other things for a long time. ‘We drew and built model boats and planes, so I knew the process. My father taught us how to use tools. I also fixed and customized instruments for my friends.’

Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a job. ‘I also liked painting and sculpture,’ he says. After school, he decided to study architecture at university. ‘Architecture is about design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good idea,’ he remembers. But he left the course halfway through. ‘I was too independent for it,’ he says. ‘But I realized I wanted to build guitars. It’s like sculpture because you shape sound. And it seemed more practical than pure art because you make things people use.’

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. At first, he sold guitars for just the cost of the materials, but as he became known as a great guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is ‘still just getting by.’ He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income. In the early years, he worked hard to become known. He went to music festivals on weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his guitars, which was hard for him.

Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought the best acoustic guitars were made in the USA,’ he says. ‘UK-made guitars weren’t seen as good, even though we have always had good courses and skills here. But now, our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve.’ Jonny says you can learn important skills in classes, and new instrument-makers should take courses. But he also believes in learning by trying things out. ‘Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn’t, and try different things,’ Jonny says. ‘If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If someone else teaches you, you learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’

When English people start a conversation, they often talk about the weather. This is a tradition, and it was noted by Dr. Johnson, an eighteenth-century writer, who said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they are very interested in it. However, this is not the case. 

The American writer Bill Bryson says that English weather is not exciting because it doesn't have extreme events like tornadoes or blizzards. On the other hand, English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman believes the weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that living near the ocean and a continent means you never know what weather you will get.

My research shows that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point. English people talk about the weather not because they care about it, but because it helps them start conversations. Phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Isn’t it cold?" are not really about the weather. They are ways to greet people or fill in gaps in conversation. This is similar to how monkeys groom each other to bond socially.

There are specific times when English people use weather talk. It can be a greeting, a way to start a conversation, or a topic to fill awkward silences. This happens often, so people from other countries might think English people are obsessed with the weather. An English conversation might start with weather talk, use it to break the ice, and return to it if there is nothing else to say. This is why it seems like English people talk about the weather a lot.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. But they really wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. When she couldn't find a historical novel to help explain life at the Wall in Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started a new career as an author in 2001. She felt it was a big change. ‘Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very tiring. Writing is exciting but not as exhausting. My old teaching friends are jealous because I still connect with children through my stories.’ Alice wants her books to fill a gap in children’s fiction. ‘Many books for teenagers today are about negative experiences. They are well written,’ she adds, ‘but they are often dark or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.’ Alice always taught English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy, and she loves seeing children go from bored to interested. She sees writing as a way to keep teaching. She was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher also suggested she try a creative writing course. At first, Alice didn’t want to do it, but she had to send her best piece of fiction to join the course. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. After sending it, she was accepted into the course. Other students liked her story and suggested she publish it. With only school report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked for a year off to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and he helped her a lot. Alice says, ‘My mother-in-law thinks we are rival authors, but we work well together. He helps improve my writing by changing sentences and suggesting new words. I like to add more scenes. That’s the difference between a writer and an editor.’

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. The race would be between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the wild and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny would drive a car on the roads, while his younger brother Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 

‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views – and it’s very cold now, so I’ll be warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. Unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, Alistair wore full winter cycling clothes. He was confident despite the cold. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’

The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to finish at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, which is 350 meters up. This was not a problem for the car, but Alistair had a tough start with a steep hill. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss, while Jonny got in the car and drove on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny’s confidence was tested right away. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first problem: a giant tractor came onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he joked to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor moved, Jonny continued driving into the morning mist.

Alistair was having a hard time with the hill. Just a couple of miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched him as he kept going with his bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side, the ground was open, and with the sun coming out, he could go faster. He put his head down, feet on the pedals, and picked up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The villages in this part of Yorkshire are very old, and the roads are not made for fast driving. Jonny had to drive slowly around a narrow corner and through a stream on the road. Once past the last village, he drove straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped to Fleet Moss, Alistair was crossing his last field and getting back on the road from the other side. He pedaled hard and then stopped quickly as he reached the line. 

Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, ‘Is he here?’ When they said no, he raised his arms in victory. Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said, feeling disappointed. ‘I’m gutted.’

Text: 'When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, the first thing you notice is the silence. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds make you feel like you are in a different world. The quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to think only about the game and the point I’m playing. When a point is over, the silence breaks with applause and cheers. I hear them, but they feel far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching me closely or the millions watching on TV as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who is my coach, always told me it was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I would play there and win. Before 2008, I played and lost twice to Federer – in the finals the two years before. Losing in 2006 wasn’t too hard because I was just happy to be there at age twenty. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better, and it was my mind, not my skills, that let me down. I cried a lot after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it’s worse when you had a chance to win. My uncle Toni, who is a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me, even when I win. But after that loss, he told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I told him he didn’t understand, that it might have been my last chance. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I missed a big one in 2007. But Toni was right. I got another chance in 2008, just one year later. I was sure I learned from my defeat the year before, and this time my mind was strong. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends. We didn’t talk about the match because I was already thinking about it in my mind. Until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

In April 1957, a young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa. She wrote to her family saying, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made her famous with articles and TV shows about her research on chimpanzees. Jane also wrote popular books, including the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century, possibly only second to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes hides her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventures and dreams but do not fully show what she has done. Jane Goodall should be seen as a leading scientist because of her research, her students who became important scientists, and the large amount of data she collected over 40 years.

Jane's main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We also did not know that they have emotions and social systems similar to humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her study in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements.

Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves because chimpanzees are our closest relatives. Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. When she was five, she disappeared one day, and her family and police searched for her. She was found with straw in her hair and explained that she had been hiding in a henhouse to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity was an early sign of her future as a biologist.

During our first conversation, which lasted an hour, Shirley Ford talks to me using different voices. She sounds like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say many medical words.’ Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it. You have to make the script come alive for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a normal acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a big part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of a job that includes many things from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and happy. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; working with other actors makes a big difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists make them.’ She says she got to where she is – near the top of her profession – through hard work as much as natural talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a love for human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a certain kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because being a cartoonist is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people give up these dreams and choose more realistic jobs, like being a lawyer or working in a factory. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like the ones in school notebooks, seems silly. But some people do it. 

People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and showed my drawings to different companies after graduating. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on.
