To be a cartoonist, you don’t need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The job is tough, and you should only try it if you can't imagine doing anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't say no to any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists had regular jobs with newspapers and magazines, but those days are ending. Now, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than those who are very artistic but lack business sense.

I often meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won't show their work to anyone! To protect your work, just draw a small 'c' for 'copyright,' put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it's more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and getting rid of things I didn't need. I decided to throw away an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to get rid of it? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man came up to me. He looked confused and asked, "Are you really going to throw that away?" I said yes, but I already felt a bit sad about it. He asked if he could have it, and I agreed. We went our separate ways. 

In the years after, I often felt sad about losing the guitar. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. The email was from a man named Keith Rushton, who restores guitars. He told me, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy I almost cried. Keith's price was fair, and I was grateful. 

My dad used to put name-and-address stickers on everything I owned, including the guitar. He would have laughed at this story! My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s because it was popular then. I loved the sound, but I didn't get very good at it. So, I switched to the electric guitar, which was easier to play. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn't have to be a great musician to be a rock star.

When I got my guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. The guitar felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I picked it up and felt like I needed to stand up to play it. My fingers remembered how to play the chords, even though I couldn't draw them. My fingertips hurt a bit from pressing the strings, but it felt good. The electric guitar is not really for playing alone, so maybe I need to start a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep well, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is getting more attention now. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them. We often lose dreams when we wake up early. The last hour or two of sleep, which we often miss, is mostly REM sleep, where we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM sleep, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM sleep. When people are deprived of REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests that dreams are important. When researchers found REM sleep in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who thought that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. But later research did not fully support this idea. Now, dream studies focus more on the physical origins of dreams. Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. He concluded that people who are interested in creativity use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Dreams, according to Stickgold, help us connect things in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new ideas. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create new combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They ignore the obvious and connect things in unexpected ways. This is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come to me so quickly that I can barely type fast enough. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small town by the sea in south-west England. In her studio, you can see empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leader in the copyist art movement, which means she can paint copies of famous artworks. She can make a painting look like a 20th-century impressionist masterpiece or a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait. But she doesn't keep her own paintings because they sell quickly. Susie is very popular. In her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has copied works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the real paintings are worth millions, Susie's copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how long she spends on them. Susie doesn't usually say who buys her paintings, but her clients include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors like to show off their 'Van Gogh' paintings, even though they are actually 'Susie Ray Van Goghs'. Some people use her copies to save on house insurance by keeping the original in a bank. Susie is honest about her work. She makes her copies look very real and signs her name on the back. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and Susie has never done that. She knows people who have, but they often get into trouble. Susie isn't rich and has had hard times, but her life is more stable now. She used to work as an illustrator for a botanical garden after her art degree, but it didn't pay well. It was good practice for her current work, and she learned to love plants. She advises young artists to learn to draw well and study a lot. Susie can draw anything from plants to 15th-century masterpieces, but she now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie says it's not. The impressionists painted quickly but were also very careful, which is hard to do. Susie doesn't create her own original art because she enjoys making copies and earns a good living from it. She has tried her own art, like painting fishing nets, but they just looked like photos. Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything else. She wanted to be the fastest person on the water. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, normal life seemed unimportant. People always wanted to know about the race, and she quickly wanted to return to the ocean. She liked testing herself against nature, even in dangerous places.

After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and work space for 94 days. She talked about how carefully she planned everything, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. Preparation was very important to her. She proudly showed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical items. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and needing protection. Her view changed after a trip to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic. There, she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. She saw many abandoned whaling stations and felt it was a warning. It seemed like people just took what they wanted and left. 

When I visited Ellen’s office, she explained why we must act now to save the planet. She said, "No one is making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious and limited. We need to find ways to not use them up." At first, her message was to use less, but then she started talking about re-using things, like reusable carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our use of non-renewable resources. 

Ellen started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about a sustainable future. She misses the adventure of being at sea, but she feels her new work is more important. She says, "I may have been the fastest around the world, but this is the most important thing I’ve ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he could become very famous. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan wants to inspire them to go outside and try new things. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

Some experienced climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb Everest. They believe a young climber might be strong enough physically, but they worry if a teenager is emotionally ready. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to make good decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.'

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father loves adventure? Paul says, 'This is not about me becoming famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later, but we decided, why not now? We always check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on reaching my goal.'

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record challenge. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This is a challenge for Jordan. People might say that focusing on records takes away the fun, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to share his story with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I am studying music at university, but even my classmates don't know much about classical music. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't have their music. The numbers are not good for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and a typical classical album sells only about 300 copies. I find this hard to believe. Why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who buy the most music and concert tickets. Some teenagers do go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but I probably listen to classical music as little as that 3% figure suggests. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk, play, and think fast. Experts say we can't focus for more than about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more interesting to us than long classical pieces without words. Classical music is powerful but doesn't deal with issues that matter to teenagers. How we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people are going to classical concerts now, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why more people like classical concerts as they get older, but I know that if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are excited to play it in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They like classical music when they play it, but it's not their first choice when they relax. For that, it's always pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said quietly to the school. Her mother was getting out of the car too, but she didn’t hear Bonnie. Bonnie didn’t mind if her mother heard because she knew how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school with many buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside. It was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre. "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be thrown out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. Bonnie liked horses and treated them well. The horses were well cared for, she could see that. Almost every stall had a horse, and she looked at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition." His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle," she thought. The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, which made Bonnie happy. She was so focused on putting a saddle on Maverick that she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed when she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The movement was exciting, and the breeze felt nice on her face. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by how confident he is. Cody is a 15-year-old from Australia who has already made some very popular songs. But how did a relaxed surfer become a star with thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I started playing guitar when I was six and writing songs at seven. But I was also swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted a few videos online." These videos changed everything for him. He started by posting a video of him and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans loved it and asked for more videos on social media. Cody, who had recorded more songs at home, was happy to share them. The response was amazing. Cody was also a very good swimmer. He trained with top coaches and focused on swimming. But then music companies noticed him, and he had to make a big decision: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a risk by signing a music deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine, at 12 or 13, trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked faces. "I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family to the US, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him. Cody says it’s important to have good people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, everyone has days of doubt. "Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about that sometimes, but my family always reassures me that they’re here to support me." Success, in any career, comes from being willing to say "yes" to big opportunities, even when they’re a bit scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be visiting countries I never thought I’d see and playing in front of so many fans – it’s like a dream that many people have. But I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. There was a new crack in the ice shining in the morning sun. I looked up the river towards the sandbags that were there to stop the buildings from flooding when the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags. Last week, I worked with many people from the town for long hours to show I could do it. But my grandfather didn’t seem to notice. 

With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile of dark water made by the factory in Milltown. There was ice on both sides, and then solid ice downstream. As I changed out of my pyjamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. He was trying to walk on the ice near the warm water from the factory. I put on my kayaking jacket and checked the pocket for my lucky chain. It’s a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip, which I read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen.

‘Morning, Rex,’ Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa. ‘Watch where you’re going!’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ My wetsuit should have made that clear. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went into the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom came over with a kind smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’s always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a kid, he was my hero. He showed me his photos in National Geographic. Those old photos are still on his wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies now, and maybe one day, my own photo in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay close to him, even if he’s grumpy. 

Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back and peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my trip.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I hurried to the boathouse in the backyard.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was a painting without a frame. It was clearly Grandpa's work, but different from anything he had done before, and it wasn't finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on something." Jess looked at the picture. There was a river in the scene, but it wasn't a river she knew. It might not even be a real river, just an imaginary one. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green, and the eye was drawn to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it seemed right that way. It felt like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, hiding her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? I mean, for him to be so specific. Maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not the artist's job to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." "Inspire?" "Someone who gives an artist ideas." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually, he said the muse wasn't helping him today, or he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on. He never suggested the muse was her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a person. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's knife in my hand, the knife might have cut the carpet by itself. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I will cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm unlucky that way.

I wasn't really thinking about cutting holes. I was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's small, white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it. I keep my shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her cabinet, so I was excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it needs to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But Angela is only fifteen, so I'll be in my small room for a while. I don't mind; I like my cosy room. The roof slopes down, and the window is at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried to fit Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was a bit too tall. If I could just cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom... Then I thought, if I can't cut the cabinet, maybe I can cut the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased because he always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly take things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' view, not a human one, which made filming more difficult. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' view. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully strange. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act at all. One important thing for me was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off because she was sewn into it every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t very accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series was successful in showing the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists, but there are none. I wonder how long it will take before things get crazy. It always happens: fake smiles, people pretending to be friends, and asking for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. "Everything’s going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the band is here for recording, we’re staying for good. I chose this school because I want to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who cuts grass. That would be so normal. 

I walk into the school’s main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the school secretary. "Name?" she asks, not very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused. "Oh," she says and types "McGraw" on her keyboard. Not many people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it’s printing," she says. She hands me the schedule. English Literature is my first class. I like English, so that’s good. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t get lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already calling roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. Nobody will suspect anything now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says. "Here." The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them, she lets us socialize. All teachers should do this. "So why’d you move here?" my new friend asks. I have many choices. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else pick a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Everyone will find out eventually. But I can pretend to be normal for now. "He’s an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I’m Becca, by the way." And she doesn’t seem to care. Perfect.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do many things. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being a teenager in America is like now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and be average. Being average is not enough anymore. If you don't have big goals, people might think you are lazy. 

Teenagers have a lot of pressure. They have homework, tests, activities after school, jobs, chores at home, and they also try to have a social life. Kristen Loose, a teenager, says that even with all these pressures, people still think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, and only care about themselves. While some teenagers might be like this, it is not fair to say all teenagers are the same. 

Many people think teenagers spend all their time watching TV or on their phones. Kristen Loose says this is not true. She keeps her phone close, but not just for fun. It helps her stay connected and manage her life. Today, students need to be connected to the world all the time, which can look like they are addicted to their phones. With smartphones and tablets, students can do their homework anywhere. Schoolwork and activities now need attention all the time, not just at school.

Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the nine hours of sleep they need. A survey found that only 20% of American teenagers get enough sleep. Also, 28% of them fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are so tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she only has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. She doesn't waste this time on social media or TV. Instead, she likes to volunteer. Olsen says people think teenagers only care about themselves, but she enjoys helping others. Her favorite part of the week is when she volunteers. She wants to make a positive impact in her school and community.

In the future, the stereotype of teenagers might change, but they will still be proving it wrong and making the world better. There will be new students who will do amazing things even before they finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a small town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the past few years, this group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project that mixes astronomy with adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to launch a high-altitude balloon to try and record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside the box, there was a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes. Two GPS trackers were on the outside to help find the box later. A gas tank, given by someone from a nearby state, was used to fill the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy had driven seven hours to get the gas. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it was time to launch. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they counted, and the balloon started to rise. Some of them ran and followed its path with strong flashlights until they couldn't see it anymore. There was a quiet and a shared feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky. It was hard to believe they were just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor crossed the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon gets bigger until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is not much inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who said they’ve only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘It’s important to remember that these students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What seems wild and dangerous to some is just normal life to others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It was a bit disappointing, but it was also a chance to talk about atmospheric waves and how they work over mountains. And it was another adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan admits that she wasn't interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. It happened by chance when she helped her younger brother with a science project about dinosaurs. She found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology, and it amazed her. She realized she wanted to learn more about it. 

Chloe remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous. She was nervous at first, worried he might think she was just a kid bothering him with questions. But he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

Chloe talks about how movies and TV shows often show palaeontologists in a misleading way. Films like Jurassic Park have made people interested in dinosaurs, but they don't always show what palaeontologists really do. Chloe explains that her job is varied. She digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs analyzing fossils, and writes for scientific publications. She also thinks it's important to explain science to the public, especially to young people, to help them understand more about the natural world.

Chloe worked on the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she helped make sure the dinosaurs were shown accurately. She says the dinosaurs in the show are very life-like and different from those in movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of adventure and discovery. They remind us that there is still much to learn about the world, and Palaeontology is like a form of time travel.

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you probably know you are not "there yet," even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" Once you arrive, it becomes "here," not "there." So, if you think you might be "there," you should ask, "Are we here yet?" Parents probably want to be "there" more than kids do because they hear this question a lot during long car trips.

Think about it: as kids, we get to relax in the back seat. We can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while the scenery passes by outside. In the front seat, mum or dad is like a helper, giving out juice boxes and cookies, changing the radio, and making sure everything is okay.

But sometimes, things go wrong. For example, my younger brother Tim might put his foot on my side of the seat. I don't like that, so I put my foot on his side. Then he might move more, and soon we are fighting. Mum or dad has to stop us and tell Tim to stay in his seat. This calms things down for a while.

Later, I might feel a breeze on my arm, even though the window is closed. It's Tim, blowing air on me from his seat. He is not touching me, so he thinks he is not doing anything wrong. This makes me angry, and Tim gets in trouble again. Then things calm down once more.

Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us. When we ask, "Are we there yet?" he sometimes says, "Yes, we are here. Get out of the car." But we are still on the highway, so we know we are not there yet. This makes us quiet for a while.

You know you are finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move away from the kids. So remember, if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you are not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and come back. Zuzi says they started this business because everyone is always on their phones and gadgets. They wanted to bring people together without screens. 

In their café, people play games called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, made by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources. Everyone stays involved, and no one feels left out. Later, 'co-operative' games were created, where players win or lose as a team, which makes people talk more. 

One popular Eurogame is Pandemic, made by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a game called Lord of the Rings. He wanted to create a game where everyone feels good, win or lose. As a child, Leacock loved games but often felt disappointed by them. With his uncle, he tried to make better games. Pandemic became very successful, and its next version included more storytelling, like in video games.

The video game industry has helped board games become popular. Many people now play games on their phones, so more people are open to playing games. Video games and board games have learned from each other. Before, people played video games together in the same room. Now, many video games are played online, so people are looking for games to play with others in person. 

John and Zuzi's café shows that board games are more than just fun. In our online world, games are a way to connect with others in real life, and this trend is growing.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many false beginnings. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she helped him start playing the guitar. The only radio station he heard at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced him as he grew up. He says he was 12 before he heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. He says, ‘I was good at tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. It was too much hard work.’ At 17, he left school to try to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to make music, that he wrote lyrics in economics class, and played piano every day. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to get a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. But record labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he split with his friend. In the end, he became famous behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. Fame and fortune did not come. He says, ‘In my artist career, I was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, I was in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for others is where he found success. He says, ‘I think I am one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to.’ This helps start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that writing with the charts in mind is okay. He asks, ‘Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?’ He believes they should write songs that are amazing and sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone speak honestly about wanting to write number one songs. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write hits and has the talent to do it. He focuses on writing the best music. ‘When I go into the studio, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of next year. It’s not just about being cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs.’

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online, but people who don't watch online videos of bike stunts might not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist.' This means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online.

I met Tony at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. Many local boys and even older people knew him and called him a 'legend.' After watching his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, Tony explained what he wanted to do, and I wasn't always sure he could do it. But he did, and when I praised him, he didn't seem very excited. Even though he is famous online, Tony doesn't like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to talk to fans and prefers doing stunts instead of talking about them.

Tony's fame comes from social media and new camera technology. This technology helps him make a living from his videos. He sometimes feels that people focus too much on cameras and screens, but he doesn't complain. Thanks to his videos, he earns money from what used to be just a hobby.

From my experience with top athletes, I know that two things are important to become great: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent. In risky sports, you need mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times but got up and tried again until he succeeded.

Not everyone thinks Tony is a hero. Some say he takes too many risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport. They don't know the technical details or that he gets expert advice to stay safe. Tony is careful about risks. He says some people never feel scared, but he does. He finds a way to overcome fear. He plans and prepares a lot before trying a new stunt. He knows he must stay calm and focused to succeed.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert in high-wire walking. Even though she had some circus skills, she found high-wire walking very different. ‘The training was a surprise,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know I needed to be so strong. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, then an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could continue if I slipped. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterward. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ But this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he wrote a book about traveling around Canada in a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a normal touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 because of a knee injury, he finally started his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got very sick and had to stay in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or to go back home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, and my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are worried about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better plans to protect their habitat. The work is hard. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have to take a boat to some areas and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather is not always good – some nights are mild, but often it is wet. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what we will do in the summer – spending hours in a lab to look at our results. It will be hard to stay inside, but it is important to do this. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it. But it's true! I work by eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Every week, I get small samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make. I also give samples to my colleagues, which makes them happy! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to go to during the day. Every day is different in this job. Sometimes I am in our food lab, and other times I travel to buy raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety and the fact that there is no routine, although I think I love the chocolate even more! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I still enjoy eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which means flying through the air above an amazed audience. In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see how they are doing. Sophia says, “For a circus career, performers need to do different things all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great thing is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work for a short time each year. But the real issue is planning for the future because you can only travel with the circus while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many past students have started businesses all over the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, it’s not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but a lot of fun!”

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you have probably heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She helps the main singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true. They often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music world!

Mariam says, "What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing. It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job."

"Excellent musical skills are very important for my work, and I need to learn quickly. There is often no written music to look at. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, and nobody likes that. Recording sessions are long enough already."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to make it better."

Julie Deane started her business with only a little fashion knowledge. She created a successful company selling 'satchels,' which are traditional school bags. These bags are now sold in famous stores and are popular with celebrities. Before choosing to make satchels, Julie thought about different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She didn't just go with her first idea. When she chose satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She worked with her family from the beginning, especially her mother, who had a natural talent for business. The design of the bags came from children's storybooks. Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her a lot. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To get more interest, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest grew. Her company now makes satchels faster. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity is pictured with a satchel. Instead of spending money on online ads, she uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh. There was a difficult time when another company copied her design. Now, she makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. People say her office has a positive atmosphere, and employees love working there. There is a new factory, but it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her swimming coach thought she could become a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to balance training with schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky thought it looked exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily go to training after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. Then, at 28, she stopped competing. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together as part of a group.’ The charity uses famous people to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people aren’t sure if having celebrities is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it to promote themselves, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Her parents were not musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to become more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she joined a songwriting course taught by a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many others. But Ana felt the teacher didn’t listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about her feelings. She posted it online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the words each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to ask her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn’t know the company and didn’t want anyone telling her what to sing. Joss convinced her this wouldn’t happen, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was an amazing night. Ana says she prefers writing songs about difficult times because there is more to say. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it made him unhappy. While she hopes fans like her songs, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an amazing trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit the area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could go too, and he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. But luckily, the weather forecast said the seas would be calm when we were there. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to think about what needed to be done. But Harry promised he had taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying.

After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our few supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide said that very few people lived along that coast. On the first morning, the only other living creatures we saw were dolphins and birds. We knew there were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far. So, I just focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches along the coast. They were full of amazing colored fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was great to stop worrying about time. We never forgot lunch or dinner, though, which we all made together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it felt like stress-free living!

When it was time to leave, I was sad. How could I return to normal life again? But I knew if I stayed, I’d miss my family and friends. I was also looking forward to telling everyone at home about our adventures!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think that watching so many games would make me love basketball, but it did the opposite. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually took a book to read instead of watching the game. 

When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. My sports teacher saw my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing a real game. However, my teacher believed in me more than I did. After a few weeks, I agreed to play against another school. My mum and dad came to watch, which made me nervous, but it went well in the end!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I didn’t have much time with friends because of training, so that part didn’t change much. I got used to my new life, and my English got better quickly!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after moving to the USA. I was taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I was too light for my height, so I had to fix that first. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college. I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. I thought about different jobs and decided to become a weekend tour guide in my city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city and was surprised by how much I liked it. I saw my city in a new way through the eyes of tourists. After I finished my studies, I wanted to be a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but I learned that I needed a lot more knowledge to get a tour guide license. In Chicago, guides must answer many questions about the city, like its buildings, history, and public transport rules. After some hard but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and became an independent tour guide. Being a tour guide is not just about knowing facts or keeping the group together. You need other skills too. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories. You also need to handle changes, like if a place is closed or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organized tour, not hear about problems. I make sure visitors are happy with my tours because bad reviews online can hurt my business. Good reviews bring more customers. I work hard to make my tours fun and stress-free. My energy and enthusiasm help me get good reviews, and people often recommend my tours to others visiting Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Josie is five years younger than me, but we get along well. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary. This is a place where people take care of sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. But in the end, we did not need to worry.

One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it very hard, but I thought it was worth it to see the elephants enjoy their food. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I found this very fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I liked most was the evening. We walked with the elephants into the forest where they stayed at night. All the volunteers lived in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so it was small. We chose to share because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not have meat, which we do not like. After dinner, we talked and played games with the other volunteers and staff.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she liked the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I am not sure she is being completely honest. I think she might be a bit upset with herself because she missed her friends too much and did not enjoy her time there fully. But when she thinks about it, she knows she was lucky to go there. Maybe she will go back one day—I definitely will!

My name is Gina D’Costa, and I have a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers to many different people. Some people buy flowers for their friends or homes, but we also have other customers. Hotels and offices like to have flowers in their Reception areas. Sometimes, we help with photo sessions for businesses by giving them flowers for their advertising pictures. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very proud of it.

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still sleeping at that time, and my friends think I am crazy, but I love my job. It is often cold and dark, but I don’t mind because I am excited about my work. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The colors and smells make it hard to choose. If I chose for myself, I would only get pink flowers because it is my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like and what other people want are not always the same. Sometimes, I cannot find the flowers that customers want because not all flowers are available all year.

I don’t really like arguing about prices with the flower sellers, but it is part of the job. Flowers are not cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought. Then, we make flower bunches and calculate how much the orders will cost. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to choose different flowers. Some people might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy finding the best flowers for the money someone wants to spend. That is what you have to do when you sell things, and I wouldn’t want any other job!

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the new films I want to see, and many films for kids on the weekends. It is close to where I live. But a year ago, I felt something was missing – talking about a film with a group of people after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema to show the films. Instead, we pick a different place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the perfect atmosphere for the film, and it was amazing! Some places we use are even free because the owners make money by selling snacks during the film, so we can keep our prices low. We just want to cover our costs, not make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier for us, especially now that we have our own equipment. We also know how many tickets we’ve sold because everything is online, so we don’t worry about empty seats! There is still a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us they had a great time, it feels wonderful. The website has helped us a lot, and we are now in contact with other film clubs across the country. We have visited other clubs to see how they do things, but it’s always nice to come back to our own club! We’ve started a blog too, because most people now look online for information about films instead of reading local newspapers. We’ve also tried putting up posters in cafés. But nothing works as well as people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we do with each film – last month we had a movie quiz, and everyone enjoyed it.

When I was a child, taking photographs was my favorite thing to do. When I turned 15, I wanted to make my hobby more serious. So, I started a special project: I decided to take one photo every day for a whole year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. After a few weeks, I put my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to make a photo diary and show my photos to other people. I was surprised to find out that some people liked how I took pictures. I enjoyed taking photos of many different things. Then, someone suggested that my project would be better if all my photos had a common theme. I agreed and started focusing on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were in black and white, which was different from other young photographers who took color photos. Sometimes, I doubted my project and almost stopped. But I trusted my feelings and became more confident in my style. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget when the judges said I won first prize; I was so happy because my project was important to me. It was the first time I thought my photography might be good enough to become a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I am happy with my career choice.

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try camping, sailing, and learn skills like public speaking. These were things I had never done before. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, and adult volunteers called 'leaders' run them. When you finish each level, you get a certificate.

When I first joined, my leader suggested I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I wasn’t sure about it because I had joined that club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. But I decided to try the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate.

Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. When I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I had made good relationships with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week and I really look forward to it.

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about this before starting at the club. In fact, I had never thought about my future job, and the idea of youth work never came to my mind. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have several other NYC certificates now, and yes, one of them is for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA. I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, and my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was young and hadn't thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to love it too. He made it look easy, and in the end, I did well. After that, I quickly started to love snowboarding and got better at it. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but I still love competing and winning. This helps me try harder. I like not having a fixed plan. Once, I became the first female to get a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn't sure I would try the jumps that got me this score until I started. This made me trust my abilities more. In the summer, I focus on training and studying because there is no snow. I train every day, but I don't have to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends. This helps me when I can't snowboard, which I love and am good at. I have to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I also want to have another option in case I don't become a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I am thinking about becoming a doctor if I can find time for college. I can't imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can't do it forever.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it only if I paid for it myself. So, I decided to work part-time and save money. I learned a valuable lesson from this. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't like it much. My parents suggested I start my own small business. I saw my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it too. I thought it would be hard, but it was easier than I expected. My friends thought it was boring, but I liked the idea. Mum showed me how to make nice things at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first jewellery to friends and family. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. I wanted to know if other people would like them too. So, I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists come to my town, and they bought a lot of my jewellery to take home as gifts. Soon, people from all over the country called to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just my mum and me at the market stall! That's when I knew it could work, and I decided to make a website. Since then, I have made a lot of money from my business, mostly online, but we still have our market stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a book called Being Amelia, which became very popular. Being Amelia is partly about Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine said, "Because of my dad’s job, my family moved around a lot, so I got good at making new friends. I know what it’s like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about how Amelia, the main character, does in a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially with her older brother. Since I’m an only child, I had to imagine that part." Janine started writing her book one summer when she was bored at home. Her mom always wanted to be a writer, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it seemed like a good way for Janine to spend her time. The year before, she won first prize in a short story competition on a young writers’ website.
