That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were excited to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s book was in stores. One review of Being Amelia says that even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters in the story face some tough challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer says that even though Janine is young and her book isn’t very long, she is a better writer than some other popular authors. Janine is still getting used to being famous: "At first, I hid when people recognized me on the street, but now it’s OK. I’d like to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I just hang out with my friends, and soon I have something interesting to write about!"

I'm Tom, I'm fifteen years old, and three years ago my family and I moved to a castle on a small island! It all started when my dad got a job as the castle's manager. He works for a group that takes care of old buildings and keeps them open for people to visit. He was happy because he thought he might not get such a great chance again, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree he should take the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like – we knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our nice home across the water, and there was no school. But after we moved, we quickly got used to living on the island. The castle isn't very beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. In summer, the island feels lively because many visitors come, and there are often parties on the beach. In winter, we only see the other families who live on the island, and there aren't as many teenagers as I hoped. The adults help each other with repairs on the island, which is often hard work. The biggest change for me was traveling by boat every day to my old school. I was excited about going on stormy days with big waves – but the ferries don't run then! And if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is a problem. So when friends come home with me, I always tell them to hurry up! But we often see amazing views, like when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it's so foggy you can't see anything, then a few hours later it's sunny again – it's still surprising when that happens, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do get bad storms, and I sometimes worry if the castle is strong enough to stay safe. But then I remember it's been here for hundreds of years – and it's still standing!

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby called birdwatching. I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural home. I spent hours watching them with my parents. They taught me how to tell different bird species apart and where to find the best places to see them. It was amazing! After we came back home, I joined a local club for young birdwatchers. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am almost there. During family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list. I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America. I thought I might see my 200th bird species there. I didn’t feel too bad when it didn’t happen because I learned that you need to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about my challenge, and many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fun hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I wasn’t nervous until just before I went on stage. I knew what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I did well and they enjoyed it. I might do another one next year! I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think about birdwatching, but there are many birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.

I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and after some time, I became a good player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then stopped them, so they probably thought I would do the same with football. But I didn’t. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee noticed I was a good player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. She was impressed and asked me to join her club. I couldn’t believe it at first because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But I started training with a big club when I was just 13. I got much better. Even so, some people didn’t think I would become a star player, which made me a bit sad. But the coach told me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s important matches earlier than I thought! I ran very hard because I didn’t want the other players to blame me if we lost. Then, by luck, I scored the winning goal. Even with the big crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, the team carried me around the field. It was amazing! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. We want to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to talk to other players in my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to think they can play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few bad times, so I’ve been lucky!

In recent years, universities in the UK and around the world have started encouraging students to get involved in research early in their studies. This is because research is not just for famous scholars or scientists. It is a natural way to learn and build skills. Research skills are useful not only in school but also in jobs because they help us think about the world and our work. As a student, you help create knowledge. You don't just learn and repeat it; you make it. Creating knowledge means asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are part of what we call research.

Research can be very complex and done by experts, but it can also be simple and part of everyday life. For example, when you plan a holiday, grow plants, fix things at home, or choose the right music system, you are doing research. In college, you are expected to have an enquiring mind, find problems and questions, explore information, and create your own ideas. Some students might find this hard because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as something you get from teachers and books without questioning it. But in the UK, US, and many other places, questioning knowledge and authorities is important.

Critical thinking is very important in research. We need to not just repeat what we read but think about it, test it, and see if it makes sense. We should not just accept information without questioning it.

Cities have always been places where people share ideas. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In modern Paris, artists like Pablo Picasso discussed art in cafés. However, living in a city is not always easy. The same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. Cities can be creative places, but they can also be stressful and unnatural.

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains. They have found that living in a city can make us think less clearly. One reason is the lack of nature. Studies show that hospital patients heal faster when they can see trees. Even a small view of nature can help our brains because it gives us a break from city life.

More people now live in cities than ever before. Instead of open spaces, we live in crowded areas with many strangers. This can affect our mental and physical health. Walking in a busy city requires our brains to pay attention to many things, like other people and traffic. This constant focus uses a lot of our brain's energy.

Natural places, on the other hand, do not need as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, created by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He believed that being in nature helps our brains relax and recover. Natural settings capture our attention without causing stress, unlike city noises like police sirens.

People have long known that cities can be overwhelming. Philosophers and landscape architects have tried to bring nature into cities. Parks like Central Park in New York give people a break from city life. A well-designed park can quickly improve brain function. While people try many things to boost brain power, like energy drinks or changing office designs, simply walking in nature can be more effective.

Despite the challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. They remain centers of new ideas and creativity. Research shows that the busy and crowded nature of cities also leads to innovation. Just like 18th-century London, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are successful creative centers. The challenge is to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its benefits. As the saying goes, sometimes people want to leave nature and return to the city.

Where should we look for the mind? Many people think that the mind is only inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain scans to show this. However, I believe that the mind is not just in the brain. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, that objects and tools also play a part in how we think. Archaeology shows that things like stone tools, jewelry, and writing have helped shape human evolution and the mind. So, I suggest that what is outside the head can also be part of the mind.

It is easy to think that the mind and the brain are the same because most studies focus on the brain alone. This is because brain scans require people to be away from their usual surroundings. But much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I am not saying that the brain is not important, but that the mind is more than just the brain. Human intelligence might extend into our culture and the things around us.

This idea is part of a theory I developed called Material Engagement Theory (MET). MET looks at how objects become part of our thinking process. For example, when we use clay to make numbers or use a stone to make a tool. It also studies how these processes have changed over time and what that means for our thinking.

Think of a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The stick becomes part of the person, helping them "see" through touch. The brain treats the stick as part of the body. This shows how flexible the human mind is. Our intelligence can change and adapt by using new tools and technology.

I see the human mind as always evolving. Throughout history, tools like stone tools or the internet have helped us understand and interact with the world. For humans, tools are not just for survival but for learning and discovery. This is why humans make things and how these things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity, meaning our minds change as we interact with the material world.

MET offers a new way to understand how different tools, from ancient axes to modern smartphones, have shaped and changed our minds. Technology that changes the mind might sound futuristic, but humans have been using it since we first evolved.

Photography is one of the most important inventions that changed how we see the world. In the United States, photography quickly became a big part of the culture. It was used in many areas like science, industry, art, and entertainment. Historians say that photography might be the greatest contribution of the US to the visual arts. Photography became very important in the US, and to understand its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Why was photography so popular? First, it was a mechanical process, which matched the growing interest in technology in the US. Just like steam power and railroads made the world smaller, photography brought images of the world into people's homes. Second, the camera was a tool to show personal and national identities, which were always changing. Third, the camera helped families keep a record of themselves, even if it was a bit idealized. Lastly, photographs were realistic and matched the US artists' focus on everyday life.

Photographs draw attention to what the photographer wants us to see. They are records of events, people, and things, showing what was in front of the camera. However, they also show the photographer's point of view. People often think photographs are a 'universal language,' but their meaning can be complex. A photograph's meaning can change depending on where and how it is shown, like in a newspaper or a gallery.

To understand a photograph, we need to know why it was made and how people first saw it. The same photograph can have different meanings in different places and times. In recent decades, artists like Andy Warhol have used photographs in their art in many ways. Photography has become an important part of art, working together with painting to show how we see the world.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have a mental life, which includes our thoughts and feelings. Psychology can be studied in animals like rats and monkeys, but it is mostly about humans. James believed human psychology has basic parts: thoughts and feelings, the physical world around us, and how we understand these things. Our knowledge is personal and comes from our own experiences, which may not always match scientific facts. 

We often act like amateur psychologists when we give opinions on why people behave in certain ways, like feeling unhappy or quitting their jobs. Problems happen when people see things differently. Formal psychology tries to find the best explanations for these situations. Psychologists help us tell the difference between personal thoughts and scientific facts. They study the mind and brain, but they don't fully understand how the brain works in different situations, like giving birth or watching a football game. 

Psychologists learn more by studying behavior and making guesses about what happens inside us. The mind is not easy to observe directly, so psychologists look at behavior to understand it. Psychology is like solving a puzzle, using clues from careful observation and analysis. It aims to describe, understand, predict, and control the processes it studies. Psychology helps us in many areas, like teaching children to read, designing safer machines, and helping people express their feelings.

Psychological questions have been around for a long time, but they have only been studied scientifically in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or looking into one's own mind, to find answers. This method has limits because it only shows a small part of the brain's work. William James compared it to trying to see darkness by quickly turning on a light. Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of behavior rather than just personal reflections.

In a simple building in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum shows products that were taken off the market because almost nobody wanted to buy them. The museum is owned by a company called GfK, and the person in charge is Carol Sherry. She believes each product has its own sad story from the people who designed and sold it. 

The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, who used to work in marketing, wanted to collect a library of consumer products. He began buying a sample of every new product he could find starting in the 1960s. He discovered that most products fail, so his collection mostly includes unsuccessful ones. 

Many products in the museum were created because of a culture of optimism. People in meetings might not have realized the product would fail, or they might have ignored the signs. Marketers sometimes spend more money on a failing product to try to make it sell, instead of figuring out what went wrong.

This focus on optimism is also common in the self-help industry. People believe that if you imagine things going well, they are more likely to happen. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot found that people often think things will go better than they actually do. Her research shows that well-balanced people are usually more optimistic about their ability to influence events than those who are depressed.

Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen studied whether positive thinking about the future helps people reach their goals. Her research found that thinking too much about success can actually reduce motivation. For example, people who imagined having a successful week at work often achieved less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck says our beliefs about ability affect how we handle failure. Some people think ability is fixed and cannot change, while others believe it can grow with effort and challenges. People who think ability is fixed find failure very upsetting because they see it as proof they are not good enough. On the other hand, people who believe in growth see failure as a chance to improve. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles grow stronger when they are pushed to their limits. Having a growth mindset can make people happier, whether or not they succeed.

Sports teams often do better when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they know, but sports are changing quickly, and old ideas are being questioned. Two main reasons for this are science and money. Sports scientists want to understand what helps players do their best, and they have many ideas about home advantage. On the other hand, people who invest money in sports wonder if home advantage should matter. If players are paid well, shouldn't they play well anywhere?

Fans are also part of this discussion. For example, if Manchester United played some home games in Asia to reach fans there, would it matter? British fans think their support is important for the team. They believe their cheering helps the team score goals, but they often forget the times when cheering didn't lead to a goal.

One thing that seems true is that home fans can influence referees. In an experiment, referees watched a match with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This shows that referees might avoid making decisions that upset the home crowd.

Studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home football teams in England won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and stadiums are very similar. However, these changes don't fully explain the data.

Home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football. Baseball has the least. This might be because baseball is more about individual players, while basketball requires teamwork. Playing at home might boost team confidence.

Another reason for home advantage could be related to players' testosterone levels. These levels are higher before home games, which might be a natural response to defending their home ground. In the Rugby World Cup, some home teams won against stronger opponents by showing determination and aggression, which are signs of home advantage. As one referee said, "It's the law of the jungle out there."

Text: "‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about 50 years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is important to athletes and their coaches. The saying is interesting because its meaning is not clear. Player did not mean he was actually lucky. He meant, ‘The more I practise, the better I get.’ This idea is part of the nature-nurture debate, which asks if talent is something you are born with or something you learn. In sports, many people believe practice is more important than natural talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson said that to become an expert in any field, you need 10,000 hours of practice. This idea became popular through books like Malcolm Gladwell’s "Outliers" and others that say practice is more important than talent. However, in his book, Epstein argues that practice alone is not enough. He shows many examples to explain this. He says that studies often only look at successful people and try to explain why they are successful. Epstein travels around the world to find answers, from Kenya to Sweden, and even to Alaska. In Alaska, he learns that in a tough sled dog race, the dogs’ drive and desire are important, suggesting that both genes and environment matter. This means that determination might also be genetic. Epstein talks about the difference between nature (genes) and nurture (environment) and says both are important for top athletes. He does not ignore the importance of training or environment. For example, if Usain Bolt grew up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest runner. Epstein also looks at how genes are important in some cases and discusses race and gender. He asks why men and women compete separately if only practice matters. Sometimes, the simplest questions are the most important."

A recent international report shows that many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why children today feel this way. In her book, "Kith," she explains that children spend too much time indoors, in front of screens like TVs and computers, and have lost touch with nature. Griffiths believes this is the main problem. 

A follow-up study talked to children and found that many would be happier if they could play outside more. People over 40 often remember their own childhoods fondly, when they spent time exploring outside, swimming, or building forts. They think this was healthier than the way children live now. However, they forget that they are the ones who have made life more protective for their children, worrying about risks.

Griffiths argues that fear of danger keeps kids indoors, which benefits the toy and gadget industry. She also criticizes trends like giving medicine to restless children or making them wear goggles for playground games. She questions how common these rules are but expresses her frustration clearly.

Griffiths believes children should have freedom to explore and take risks. She says kids need small accidents to learn how to avoid bigger ones later. However, she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are safe. She also wonders if all children want to be adventurous, as some might prefer to stay home and be cautious. The real issue might be forcing all children to live the same way, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this is not because of my schooling. Most life problems cannot be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play. Those with more to learn play more. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how adults and mammals have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, and moral lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is important for economic success. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems, not just follow instructions or do routine calculations. Creative thinkers can anticipate problems before they happen. The creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his work 'combinatorial play.' He imagined chasing a sunbeam to develop his theory of relativity. We cannot teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling that focuses on set questions and answers. More important than creativity is getting along with others, caring for them, and cooperating. Children are born wanting to play with others, and this play helps them learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit anytime. To keep the game going, players must keep each other happy. This makes play very democratic. School has become harder: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and there is more pressure for high grades. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now feel they must solve children's problems. These changes have been gradual but significant. They are due to social factors like parents' fears, expert warnings about dangers, less cohesive neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the trend of the past 50 years. We must give childhood back to children. They must be allowed to play and explore to grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn help them connect directly with employers. In the past, people had to do things like stand outside an office with a "hire me" sign to get noticed. But with more access to employers, there is also a bigger chance to make mistakes.

For example, a young person in the US tried to connect with a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts that the young person thought could help him get a job. However, the executive was not happy with this request. She did not want to share her contacts with someone she did not know. She rejected his request and sent a very harsh reply, which became popular online. Many people who saw the reply were shocked, and the executive might now regret how she responded. But this situation can teach young people to be more careful when using social media for work.

Social media can be risky for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly. Many young people are making mistakes. This is surprising because sites like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of their social lives for years. When we were teenagers, social media was a place to have fun and be someone different. But using social media for work is very different, and some young people do not see the difference. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you can impress employers on LinkedIn. We need to understand that what we learned about social media as teenagers does not work for finding jobs. We must meet employers' expectations to succeed in the job market.

One common complaint from employers is that young job seekers are too casual and seem arrogant on professional sites. This makes older people think we feel entitled, but in reality, many young people are just trying hard to find jobs. This impression of arrogance can hurt their chances, even if they have the skills and motivation to be good workers.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them. Maybe you can help with research or assist in another way. This approach gives you a better chance of getting a positive response. Avoid sending impersonal messages and keep your tone humble to make a good impression. Remember, social media can help you make useful contacts, but you need to use it carefully to avoid problems.

Text: 'Predicting the future of newspapers is very difficult. If you look at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in trouble. Since 2000, the number of people buying UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to half. In the USA, only 26% of people now get their news from newspapers, compared to 45% in 2001. Some people think that printed newspapers will disappear in 15 years. However, old types of media often survive. In 1835, a journalist said books and theatre were finished, but they are still here today. Theatre survived newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio is still popular even with TV, and cinema is still strong against videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records are popular again, with sales up 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once new media too, but it took a long time for them to become the main way people got news. This happened in the mid-19th century with new technology like the steam press, railway, and telegraph. People also started to believe that everything is always changing, and they needed regular news updates. In medieval times, people only noticed the changing seasons and big events like famines or floods. Journalism as a job you could live on didn’t really exist before the 19th century. Even then, people didn’t see why they needed news every day or week. Newspapers have a fixed format and schedule, which can be limiting. Online news lets people check news when they want and follow stories that interest them. Online news can update quickly and correct mistakes fast. There is no limit to how much can be written, and you can often see full documents or events. This is very different from newspapers. However, online news often focuses on being first and getting lots of comments, which can cause confusion. In medieval times, news was shared in busy places like markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors. In some ways, we are going back to that. Newspapers have not always been great at explaining how the world works. They might disappear, or they might find a way to help us understand the world better, even as the internet makes us feel like we live in a chaotic world.'

If humans were comfortable in the light of the moon and stars, we would enjoy walking in the dark, just like many animals that are active at night. But we are daytime creatures, with eyes made for sunlight. This is a basic part of who we are, even if we don't often think about it. This is why we have changed the night by adding lots of light. This change, called light pollution, has effects that scientists are just starting to understand. Light pollution happens mostly because of poor lighting design, which lets artificial light shine into the sky instead of focusing it on the ground. This extra light changes the natural darkness of night, affecting the lives of many animals, including humans. It can change things like migration, reproduction, and feeding. 

In the past, the idea of 'light pollution' would not have made sense. For example, if you walked towards London on a moonlit night around 1800, you would not see much light from the city, even though it was the largest city in the world. People used candles, torches, and lanterns, and only a few houses had gas lights. There were no streetlights yet. 

We have lit up the night as if it were empty, but many animals are active at night. Light is very powerful and can attract animals. For example, birds can be drawn to bright lights and fly around them until they are exhausted. Birds migrating at night can crash into tall, brightly lit buildings. Some birds even sing at strange times because of artificial light. 

People used to think light pollution only bothered astronomers, who need to see the night sky clearly. But everyone needs darkness. Darkness is important for our health, just like light. Changing our natural sleep patterns can cause health problems. Our sleep and wake cycles are connected to the natural light and dark cycles of Earth. Changing these rhythms is like changing our balance. 

In the end, humans are affected by light pollution just like animals. We have lost touch with the natural night sky and the rhythms of day and night. Light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe, which we can best understand by looking at the stars and the Milky Way above us.

The founder of a big international company recently said that his company will stop keeping track of employees' paid holiday time. This idea was inspired by an internet company that did something similar. The founder got the idea from an email from his daughter, which was shared in many newspapers. Some people think this announcement is just a way to make the company look good, but we should ask: is this idea practical?

The internet company and the big international company are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the big company has 50,000 employees and many different services like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want" might work better in a smaller company where people know each other's work better. In a big company, it might be hard to know if taking time off will hurt the business.

The founder of the big company said employees can take as much leave as they want if they are sure their work is up to date and their absence won't harm the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? Even if you prepare well before a holiday, there is always a lot of work waiting when you return. This is just how taking leave works. People might feel guilty about going on holiday, which can lead to stress and lower productivity over time.

There might also be pressure from coworkers about who takes time off and for how long. In many companies, especially in the corporate world, there is a culture of working late. This could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave, where people compete for promotions. If the feeling of safety that comes with guaranteed leave is removed, people might feel they can't take the leave they need because they don't want to seem lazy.

Modern technology lets us get work messages anytime and anywhere, making it hard to separate work from free time. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees asked how this new way of working fit with the old time-off policy. They wondered why the company should track time off if it couldn't track work hours accurately. But if there are no set work hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might feel like they are always being watched, which can be stressful.

Employment laws exist to make sure workers get enough rest and leisure time, which is important for their health. The benefits of the unlimited leave policy, like better morale and creativity, can happen without affecting worker well-being. So, I am not sure if letting employees "take as much holiday as they want" is really the goal or the likely result of this policy.

Journal-based peer review is a process where experts check a scientific paper before it is published. This is to make sure the research is good and not full of mistakes. Scientists often say this process is important to keep trust in scientific work. However, reviewing a paper can take up to a year, which can delay its publication. Is this delay worth it? The answer is both yes and no. 

The world of scientific publishing is changing. I still think papers should be checked before they are published, but things are shifting. One big change is the use of preprints. Preprints are drafts of papers shared online before they are reviewed by experts. They allow new research to be shared quickly so others can read, comment, and build on it. 

Publishing in journals has become more about gaining fame and advancing careers. This can lead to authors cutting corners to get published in top journals. Reviewers now often decide if a paper is good enough for a journal, not just if it is good. This can depend on how interesting the topic is, not just the quality of the science. 

Many people know these problems, but few want to change the system. Preprints might be a solution because they don't require a big change from the current system. Some people think journals won't accept papers that have been shared as preprints, but this is not true. There is also a worry that sharing papers without review will lead to bad science, but this hasn't happened yet. 

Preprints are open for everyone to read and discuss, which helps improve the work. Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience with preprints. Her paper was a critique of another paper, which is hard to publish in traditional journals. With preprints, the original authors could respond, and everyone could see the discussion. Even if a journal rejects the paper, the preprint and comments are still available, so the work is not wasted.

Preprints allow for global scientific discussions and can share important negative results that journals often ignore. They also increase how often papers are read and cited. By using the internet's openness, preprints focus on the research itself, not just where it is published.

When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say it is like 'a painting in words'. These answers don't usually satisfy me or them. So, one day, I asked a group to choose an object and write one paragraph describing it like a scientist would, and another paragraph from the object's point of view, calling it 'Poem'. One student wrote: 

Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I help people breathe. I am used only in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need me. 

The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise was fun and led to good discussions. 

When I was in school, poetry often confused me. I thought poems were like puzzles that stopped me from understanding and feeling. After school, many people find poetry less interesting. Sometimes you see a poem, and it stands out because it is not like regular writing. It challenges you to read it, and often you feel let down because it seems plain or hard to understand. Still, you feel good for trying. 

What do we want from poems? Aren't they supposed to have deep feelings, beautiful images, or clever humor? The answer seems to be yes. But for tears, we watch movies; for information, we read articles. Novels let us escape to other worlds, paintings please our eyes, and music combines words and melody beautifully. 

However, poems can show us something important: ambiguity, or things that are not clear. Life is full of this, just like reading a poem. But this still doesn't tell us what a poem really is. If you search online for 'poem', it leads you to 'poetry': 'a form of art using the beauty and rhythm of language'. This is a fancy way to say it, but the word 'poem' comes from the Greek word 'poí?ma', meaning 'a thing made', and a poet is 'a maker of things'. 

So, if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes say poems are like wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or like machines – carefully made and precise. But these comparisons don't always work. The best part of comparing poems to other things is the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this can change how you think about machines or animals. It helps us think differently and see common things in a new way. 

A poem can be like a mental object, especially when we think about how song lyrics can stay in our minds. The mix of words and music is powerful, like schoolyard rhymes. But aren't words sometimes like sticks and stones? 

Think about a poem in a newspaper or magazine. A poem can have a strong impact, even though it is just ink on paper like the prose around it. What about the empty space around the poem? That space could be used for a longer article or ad. A poem is written and rewritten like an article or story, but it is not made to be sold. Publishers send out poetry books, but they don't expect them to make money. A poem is not for the market; it is for itself. Because of this special status, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. It cost £70, which was a lot of money back then. My wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, I have enjoyed finding brooches and coins because they make me feel connected to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had some free time and wanted to go to a place I had in mind. But it was raining, so I went to a closer spot that mostly had old farming machinery. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I couldn't ignore it and started digging. I was on my stomach in the mud when I saw a round, golden ball. I thought it might be brass, like some curtain rails I found before, so I tried not to get too excited. But as I cleaned it, I saw it was a beautiful, patterned loop. I realized it looked like the Great Torc, a famous necklace from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. 

I took it to my car and kept looking at it on the drive home. At home, I washed it in the sink. I called Marion and showed her. She was surprised. I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. At night, I hid it in our wardrobe, but I was worried, so I moved it under a floorboard in my office.

The law says you must report such finds within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc before giving it up, so I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office. The registrar was surprised when he saw it. The torc was checked and sold to my local council. Now, it is in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just money; it's something I saved for the nation. People ask if I will stop detecting now that I found something so amazing. But I still find brooches and coins interesting. Like a fisherman who catches a big fish, I won't stop while there's a chance of finding something even bigger.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things to do when I travel, but I don't talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends tell me about their busy travel plans, full of activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. I wonder what they would think if they knew my travel plans include time for naps in the afternoon and lazy mornings in bed. Sleeping better is a nice part of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. There were noisy birds nearby, but it didn't bother me. Away from home, I could sleep deeply and have dreams that were more enjoyable than I thought possible. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I think there's more to it than just relaxing. I believe sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we see, hear, and smell new things. We take in new cultures, music, and landscapes. When we sleep, we process all these new experiences. That's why sleep feels more intense when we travel. Sleep also changes with different places. People often worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local habits is more challenging than changing time zones. For example, on the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is just one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to get used to their sleep pattern. Once I do, I feel like I truly belong there. I remember an afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, we all felt sleepy and lay down on hammocks and sofas. I realized why they had so many pillows on the floor. I joined them and experienced the Latin American tradition of the siesta. I shared not just sleep, but a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is special because I remember it. Being in a new place, away from my usual routine, I enjoy the different smells, textures, and sounds while I sleep. If 'slow travel' means enjoying every moment instead of rushing, then sleep is the slowest activity. Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed and tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? Be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one looks best on you," she said kindly to her customer. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking a bit like a bulldog. "But it's so boring," she said. "Everyone will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little one will make me stand out." She patted the red and black small top hat on her head. "Yes," she said, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change the woman's mind. Smiling, she agreed that the woman would stand out at the wedding. She thought about her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen's thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family party. It had been a while since everyone was together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious to meet Jen's friend, who they knew nothing about. Her husband Jeff had been quick to comment when Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie. "Tattie," Jeff said, "What kind of name is that?" "It's short for Tatiana," Mia replied. "I think it's nice." "It sounds pretentious," Jeff said. He didn't like anything showy or fake. He also didn't like Mia's way of being too polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat. He might have even said a trash can lid would look better. "The problem with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you're too polite." An hour later, Mia closed the shop and went home. Her commute was only forty seconds because her shop was in a barn next to their house. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia decided to turn the barn into a space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think people want hats?" he asked. Mia knew from friends that there was a demand for special occasion hats. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia's Hats was a success. Women came from far away to her shop in the village of Little Pelham. In a friendly environment, they could try on many hats to find the right one. Mia also offered changing rooms and encouraged customers to bring their outfits. Recently, she started selling handbags and costume jewelry too.

Lawrence Okoye has traveled a long way from London to Atlanta. He is on an exciting sports journey. Lawrence is confident, but even he is surprised by how far he has come. He was in the Olympic final for discus throwing, and now he might join a big American football team, even though he has never played the sport before. In Atlanta, he is learning about his new position in football. It seems unbelievable that a 21-year-old from London could be chosen for a top American team, but Lawrence is used to surprising people. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on discus instead. In just 20 months, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world. Lawrence went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for discus, aiming for the world championships. He thought about American football before, but it seemed crazy. When he got to the USA, he decided to try it. He read about NFL trials in Atlanta and applied, even though he had never played before. He wasn't nervous about competing with experienced players. His test results were impressive, and he was noticed as the best player. Lawrence is proud but also careful. He knows he has a lot to learn. Coaches say he has the right skills, and it depends on how hard he works. He is relaxed about whether he will be selected for the team. He learned from his Olympic experience, where he came last in the final but was happy to qualify. Lawrence doesn't let setbacks stop him. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, which is a big motivation. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. Some people think he should focus on one sport, but he wants to follow his dreams. If football doesn't work out, he can return to discus, which he loves. Every choice he makes is well thought out.

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daylight. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green made me feel better because, even though it was mid-September, it had not started snowing in Siberia yet. I saw no signs of people, just mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow. He was flying to a remote area to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as bad as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with only a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I told him I believed there was a road, though not many people used it now. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked unsure and said "Holodna" (cold) while pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, but I didn't mention that I was on a tight budget because my trip was self-funded. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at low prices. I wasn't sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman’s over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students sitting without much energy. Some were taking notes. The lecturer kept talking. I was thinking about a problem. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me was Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy writing, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still learning to manage my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and fulfilling. Plus, there were long holidays to go on adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I used these holidays to meet Al. He loved adventure after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: to cycle around the world. Since our first ride together, Al had been taking on bigger challenges. This trip around the world by bike was his biggest challenge so far. Sometimes he thought the ride or the road would be too much for him. Even though it sounded tough, I envied him. He was having an amazing adventure, finding he could handle each new challenge, even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the people who said he couldn't do it. He was doing something that scared him almost every day, and it made him feel alive.

In the Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns flying through tall pylons, which are 15 to 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it's like to take part in this race. 

An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first said I was in good health, and the second said I would empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I also learned that I needed to stay aware of my surroundings. I was told, "The horizon is your best friend," and the pilot would tell me where to look. I was also asked to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything. When we were moving down the runway, my legs were up, and I tried not to touch the important steering pedals or switches. I decided not to relax and enjoy the flight, even though I was told to. In high-speed flying, you need to stay calm and focused. You have to tense and relax at the right times. Panicking is not good.

As we started down the runway, Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off, and we quickly turned right. It was a strong move, and I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and took short breaths. For a moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned left and dived, making my stomach feel like it was left behind. Soon, we were flying 10 meters above the ground, going between two pylons at 400 km per hour. My excitement was cut short by a sharp right turn. We hadn't even started the acrobatics yet.

For two minutes, I got to fly the plane. My hand was shaking, and the plane shook too because it was so responsive. Then Dario said something, but instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I said. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying in a full circle. Some people might find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters, but I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, when we were upside down, I heard a voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw fields.

The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what the pilots experience in a race. To show this, Dario ate sandwiches happily after we landed. I didn't eat for hours, and that night, I dreamed about doing loops again and again.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you've seen amazing videos of polar bears in nature documentaries, he probably filmed them. He likes temperatures of -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, and he learned how to survive in cold places. His big chance came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. 'I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.' He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many big TV wildlife series. 'I started at a good time. When I began, not many people had been to the Antarctic. There were people who focused on coral, elephants, or chimpanzees. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were waiting to be filmed.' The camera and communication technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. 'It is easier to film today. If you filmed something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can film a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you missed. You filmed less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.' 'My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases, or mosquitoes.' Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy job. It is a world of polar bears and is very dangerous. Usually -32C in April, the wind is strong and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very hard. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow for 23 days, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. 'We find a new hole and wait. We move around to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera’s locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye’s very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She’s looking at me but she’s not bothered. I’ve just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can’t get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I’d swear it’s partly in sheer pleasure,’ he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘Clearly it’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. He had to swim in very cold water and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he also reached the South Pole. Now, he is back in the Arctic for a new expedition that he says is even more challenging. Explorers are confident and determined people, and they need to be. This time, there is more at risk. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometer journey to the North Pole. They will take detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and the results will be very important for scientists. This will show what global warming is doing to the ice in the polar region. Pen was trained for this job. As a child, he was cared for by a woman who had worked for the famous explorer Scott of the Antarctic. She toughened him up by sending him out into blizzards with little clothing. His father gave him a love for frozen adventures, and Pen had great physical endurance. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he is at home because he is often thinking about the Arctic. For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horses compete against people on foot. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. Pen says it is harder to leave them this time. When he last went, his children were one and five years old. He told his son to take care of the family, which was too much pressure for him. So, this time, Pen plans to have little contact with them while he is in the Arctic. He is spending his last days before leaving preparing his equipment carefully. Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer, will join him. They will have a team of six people flying in supplies. Being part of a team is more stressful for Pen, and he is also worried because he is turning 47 and has not trained as much as he would like. He says organizing things always seems more urgent. Pen believes his mission is important because it helps scientists understand the Arctic. He says that reaching the North Pole was a personal goal, but this time, the data will help scientists, and they want to involve as many people as possible in learning about the Arctic Ocean. He feels that their skills are now very useful for society.

Text: I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. These activities were great, but I missed having a big competition. I wanted to stay fit in case I wanted to try for the Olympics again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle's invitation: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I love rowing and missed it, but I wasn't ready to train every day. I talked to some rowing friends about the race, but they weren't interested. I knew if I joined the race, I would want to win. Would Ben be the best partner to win? Probably not. But being an underdog with no pressure sounded interesting. I contacted Ben. He was going to do the race anyway and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat deposit, making the race possible. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but it would take work. I also had to think about losing money from not working. Speaking at business conferences is a good way to earn money as a retired athlete. It's nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Doing the race would mean I could talk about something new: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one big lesson was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but it was straightforward. I trained almost every day, but the program was set, and there were doctors and dieticians. I worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I was afraid it would look like I just wanted to be on TV. My worries went away as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about the mind than just rowing. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. But he couldn't row well. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have known his level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. I was 26 and feeling restless. I wanted to see the Arctic landscapes, with their cold and empty spaces, maybe because I was tired of the noise and crowds in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to let me work as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, many tourists come for sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow. These rides can last from an hour to five days. The company started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. They also took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm', which is a simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They said I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away.

November 6, London On my flight, I try to memorize the names of more than 100 huskies, but I feel distracted and nervous. I stop looking at the page and gaze out of the window instead. People say that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. But I feel like I am seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and rivers freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus ride north is just what I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrive at the farm after dark and am quickly given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking sounds, which get louder as I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth, getting the huskies ready and attaching them to sleds. The dogs are very excited, pulling hard on the ropes because they want to go. I can hardly hear to introduce myself, and the others are too busy to talk much. I stand on the side and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and suddenly we are off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I have to answer some tough questions about what I can do for the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I don’t know. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not very useful: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, feeling relieved. The basics of dog-sledding are easy to learn: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and giving water to the dogs become hard in the freezing weather. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is full of instructions, and my muscles ache from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled by excited huskies. But I feel proud. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, when Radcliffe ran past the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that she could have competed in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists asked her about a natural treatment called emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after she had an accident with a bike while training. Radcliffe says she didn't really realize how big her achievement was at the time. She felt it was just what she was supposed to do that day. Her team had a motto: no limits. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her team, listening to the radio. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was also there. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep up the fast pace. Hartmann was upset by this, but he understood why someone might think it was risky. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast and still managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run faster than that.’ The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would beat that time soon. Radcliffe thought she would try again next year, but it didn't happen. After the race, people wondered how she, with her awkward running style, beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with her for weeks, helping her with the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said she could handle a lot of pain. Hartmann traveled 13 hours from Ireland to her training place in France, and when he arrived, her husband said, ‘Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting.’ There was no time for a break; she wanted a two-hour session right away. Hartmann gave so much time to Radcliffe that other athletes felt left out. Can Radcliffe explain why no one has beaten her record? ‘Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people. I thought Mary Keitany might do it. Maybe it's because people race each other more than themselves.’ She means she always pushed herself, even when she was winning. Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the best of her career. She never ran that fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, "In Search of Perfection," came out, I didn't know how people would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' in Britain. I believed our show was a new and exciting part of that change. But I was worried: would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, memories, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I didn't need to worry. The show was a success and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my restaurant experiences. Each project feels like a journey, whether it's about the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I wrote several books in a series called "Perfection," each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often a real one, with travel and meeting new people. "In Search of Total Perfection" is the latest book, where you travel the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes the best golden pasta. These people have spent years trying to reach their own idea of perfection. Perfection is different for everyone. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was hard, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish wasn't included. But after long meetings, the TV team and I made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of what perfection is, based on their feelings, memories, and surroundings. I knew from the start that I wasn't saying these recipes were the best ever. But I thought that by using my skills and talking to food experts, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through trying new things. The TV series let me explore new foods, people, and places, which was very exciting. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. Some adventures included visiting a factory that had the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm that wasn't good enough to film. To perfect each recipe, I even hand-milked a cow, used dry ice to make ice cream, cooked chicken in a hospital machine, and almost set my house on fire trying to make a pizza oven hot enough!

We were still far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and went off the road into a field, stopping suddenly. John got out and looked at the engine, but after a while, he admitted, "I don’t know what I’m doing," and he and Mum started laughing. Bea was worried and said, "We can’t stay here forever." The field was big, with just grass and flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea because it was usually best to be on her side. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. John went to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay on the grass and asked me to tell a story. Bea lay down too, so I told them about hearing two birds talking in London. They talked about breadcrumbs, other birds, and the weather. They even argued about a worm. Bea said, "That’s silly, no one understands bird language." I said I did, but I wasn’t sure anymore. Mum had fallen asleep. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped push the van to a hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out, but the boys didn’t mind and waved at her. We went into a café near the road. John whispered, "It’s a hotel. It might be expensive." Mum said, "We’ll just have some tea," and we sat on the terrace. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum said, "It’s like syrup." We stayed there all day while John tried to fix the van. He said, "It’s a miracle it got us this far," as it got dark. Mum made a bed for us outside in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn’t moving. John said, "I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech." Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed with John driving it. Bea didn’t want to move, so John carried her to the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I wondered how we’d get home since our van needed to be towed. I thought maybe we could take a boat to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like Lucy. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city. Lucy didn't hear her name clearly because of the noise, but it was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to talk about the music they were playing and their travel plans.

Lucy told them, "I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer." It sounded impressive, but she didn't really want to go. She didn't want to do many of the things that filled her time, like concerts and competitions. These events took her around the world and made her miss so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. Her dad had bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her, and her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. Lucy hadn't applied to the festival herself; her mom had done it for her. Her mom said, "I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in." Lucy thought it was more like her mom didn't want her to say no.

The guy from Tokyo asked, "Tanglewood?" Lucy said, "Yeah." He asked, "How old are you?" "Fifteen," she replied. He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, "Wow." Lucy didn't mean to brag. It was hard to know when she was just sharing information or showing off. She explained, "It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're going to try..." Liesel/Louisa excused herself to talk to someone else. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, "Have you ever been to Japan?" He had long, shaggy hair, like many musician guys, to show they were cool. Lucy said, "Once. When I was, like, eight." He was about to reply when Lucy's grandfather came over. "Lucy, let me introduce you to someone," he said, pulling her away. "And don't get too friendly with the competition." Lucy said, "They're not the competition." Her grandfather replied, "Everyone is the competition."

Her grandfather took her around the room to talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, but she only heard about half of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, "You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are." Lucy liked being somebody, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn't make her special to the kids she used to go to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro well. But in places like this festival, she knew she mattered.

"It's not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world," said Dad. It's hard to argue with him, so I wanted to see what experts say about it. It's quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of who they are, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is a big part of modern childhood. Teenagers don't just use media for things like buying tickets or checking emails like adults do; they live in it. It's not good or bad – it depends on how you use it.

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it's like hanging out at a youth club, which today's parents did when they were younger. It's a virtual youth club where teenagers can develop their identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and get along with friends.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says adolescence is a time to ask, "Who am I?" Social networking can help you find your identity. You can share your favorite music or sports, discover what you like, and see that others have different views. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don't use social media. He says social media can help if you're shy because online communication can be easier than face-to-face, and you can practice social skills in a less scary environment.

Professor Andrew Phillips studies how young people use social networking sites. He thinks they can help quiet people with special interests connect with others who like the same things. If only a few people at your school like a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group with similar interests, you can feel popular in a different way.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says teenagers who find new interests online and create their own content are using social networks well. She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force. Teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what interests them. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity. Photographers can connect, learn, share images, and deepen their interest. This helps with jobs and will be useful at work. Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness, so you need to understand how it works. If you have 1000 friends on social networks, they could be customers for a product you create. Linking these networks gives you a customer base.

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and start working, agrees Matthews. Many sites offer the chance to work with others to create and share content. Collaboration is a key skill for the 21st century and important for being employable in a digital age."
