When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they probably don't imagine a long trip through nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. But my parents had a different idea for our summer vacation this year. My dad planned what many teenagers would call a nightmare: a big family road trip. Before the trip, my parents kept saying, "Not enough people do this anymore," while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There's probably a good reason why!"

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough room left for us, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our comfortable home for smaller places to stay over the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into.

We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under the darkest starry skies, but only after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way!

The next day, we were up early and on the move again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was unique. We visited the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly town gave us a hint of what we would experience later. As we climbed to our next stop, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers. Everywhere we went, we saw a mix of old and new. We got used to dealing with construction traffic. We laughed when we saw the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument.

We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common. We had a close encounter with a bear on the road, which gave us unforgettable memories.

As we continued, life back home seemed far away. Even the old hotel we stayed in, with its problems, didn't ruin our excitement. It was a 95-year-old building with no internet or cell phone service, but it had the most amazing views. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to a faraway place to find something special. It was nice to be home again, and I was happy that I hadn't fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our trip to look through and remember. For me, the best memories were the unplanned and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school, living at the college under the care of the Head. She was happy because she got the best room with a kitchen and study area, plus free Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would still watch over Amy.

Rose was moving to her grandmother's house. She only had some holiday memories of her grandmother and never knew her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not very excited, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and wanted to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn't know why her parents didn't get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Rose last saw her grandmother when she was ten, and her memories were happy.

Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and liked to bring people together. Rose expected dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips. This made Rose smile. Her grandmother was not a typical old lady and seemed to go to more social events than the Queen of England.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was sensible and mature. She knew about healthy eating, exercise, and sleep. But Rose wanted independence. She wanted to play loud music, invite friends over, or go out without asking for permission every time. She didn't want to be nagged about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood. Rose's mother gave her a new touch-screen phone with a video camera for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They agreed to trust each other. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If there were problems, they would talk about it.

Rose was not a wild child. Her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this was the last time because she would start her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger says her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed difficult. At 13, she decided to try writing a novel. Now, that novel is about to be published. When she told her old teacher, the teacher was surprised because she thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte didn’t see why she should wait if she could be good at it now.

I met Charlotte at her publisher's office. Even though I knew she was only 15, I was surprised to see such a young person. Her book is impressive: the story is strong and full of action. Nothing about it, except the age of the main character, shows it was written by a teenager. A public relations person was with us in case Charlotte needed help, but she didn’t. Charlotte is confident and smart, but also calm.

Charlotte knows she is young and doesn’t have all the answers. She says she wanted to ask big questions in her book, not answer them. She laughs and says she doesn’t have many life lessons to share. She was interested in the idea of taking responsibility.

Charlotte thinks teenagers are often shown in books in three ways: as outsiders who become accepted, as naïve and knowing nothing, or as socially awkward. She found this annoying because not all teenagers fit these types. She believes this can make teenagers doubt themselves.

Charlotte loves reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. Their books explore deep ideas, and she wondered if she could do the same. However, she found a book called "How Not to Write a Novel" helpful. It taught her that if readers can guess what happens next, the suspense is lost.

Some might think Charlotte’s parents, who are journalists, helped her get published. Her father knew someone in publishing, which helped her book get read. She knows she was lucky because getting a first novel read is hard. But she believes that after getting a chance, a writer’s success depends on their talent. She doesn’t take her success for granted.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, wanted to show he knew what he was doing. He went first, skiing down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew into the air, but something looked wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and fell head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I liked practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it, and I was afraid of being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in fake snow. Students jumped and landed in foam cubes – not a real introduction to what we’d face on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat part behind the jump before the slope goes down again. Land in the right zone, and you keep moving forward. Land on the flat, and you stop suddenly, which hurts. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs would almost stop as I got close, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being indoors, but bouncing was fun. Some exercises copied ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body does in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed right. Gareth was as happy as I was, and I felt proud. But that didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I kept my speed, jumped, and landed in the right zone. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty, and you hold on tight as the ride stops and then slowly goes up. There is a pause, and then a fast drop makes your stomach feel funny. You move quickly forward, turn left, and go upside down. Everything is a blur, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose to be there, like many others who visit theme parks every year.

Amusement parks are a big business because people love exciting rides. To make these rides, there are big teams of engineers and designers working hard. They create rides that are fun and a little scary but safe. Designing rollercoasters is not easy. It is about finding the right mix of fun and fear and making sure people want to come back for more.

Many of the ideas used in rollercoasters today were invented by John Miller in the early 1900s. Back then, rides were more extreme, but now designers have to follow rules and use certain track designs.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, who studies thrills, said the skill is in putting the ride pieces together. Dr. John Roberts explained that it is about making people feel like they are being thrown around but still safe. The best rides tell a story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and use new ideas like the tallest or fastest ride to make it exciting.

Professor Walker said that designing rollercoasters is about using experience and trying new things. Jeff Hornick, who works in theme park development, agreed that you need to love thrills to design good rides and test them before people use them.

I asked if new technology like virtual reality will change rollercoasters. Walker said that while new technology is exciting, the real rollercoaster experience will always be the most important part.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer. She has created dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both with her busy schedule. She says, ‘Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio and take orders from strict choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day.’ As a choreographer, she teaches and likes working with young students. ‘New dancers are open to trying new ideas. In some ways, it’s easier to work with students than professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed but don’t fully know their strengths and weaknesses yet. This means they accept even tough criticism. They might still question me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback.’

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. ‘There might be music I don’t like, but I still try to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose new music. I’d like to be more experimental and switch music when rehearsals are tough. But now, I work on big productions where the music is already decided by the composer and can’t be changed.’

Miranda doesn’t want to stay with one institution. ‘I think it’s important to meet new people. But I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. So, I need to adapt my work each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.’

We talk about a recent documentary on ballet dancers and choreographers. ‘Some documentaries look glamorous but are misleading,’ says Miranda. ‘This one tries to show the real life inside a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections, and I recognized it. She knows she’s not doing it right but can’t make her body do it. It’s hard to watch but not fake. People don’t realize how much work and dedication ballet requires.’

I ask what makes a great dance production for Miranda. ‘It’s when everything – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to ask, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can cover a few wrong choices. I’ve been in productions where the dance is great, but something about the costumes or props distracts. That’s disappointing.’

Miranda has done many different works, so I ask if she sees herself as a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist. ‘People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s a trend to focus on one area, but I don’t follow it. Maybe one day I’ll be known for one thing, but for now, I want to explore more.’

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation gave me the idea for a fun four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main part of the film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to hold it. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to continue. I have been on several walking trips in recent years, but this was something new. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and it was on main roads. This meant I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I often told people, "No, I'm not doing it for charity, and I'm not training for a marathon." When someone at work asks me about my weekend, I prefer to explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. The man at the Greek port was curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I explained I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. He still looked puzzled, but he smiled and showed me on board. Our group had exchanged emails before we started, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would be with us all the time, and they made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first real 1.5 km swim, and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group - not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was happy when I finally did it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in, reaching a comfortable speed, and stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. We hardly needed the support boat. I can’t wait to come again next year.

Being a flight attendant is not easy, but I love it. Since I started, I have traveled to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with great people, have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. This makes it a great job for a young person like me!

When I was a child, I went to a boarding school in another country, so I often flew alone. I felt lonely and asked the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers. Some of them let me help. I remembered this later when I wanted to leave my banking job and try something new.

At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people, and many were accepted. They were often well-qualified like me and wanted to change careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my strengths and past work experience, not just that I loved to travel. I got the job!

I recommend this job to anyone because there are many good things about it. The free flights are nice, but they are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and we have a saying: "No one’s finished till everyone’s finished." It feels like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close.

When I am not working, I don’t have to think about work. If I have difficult passengers, which doesn’t happen often, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again.

At the summer camp where I work, I love seeing the children do things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel very nervous, but after some encouragement, they try it and all of them reach the top in the end. This makes them feel very happy. 

At the start of the week, some children miss home. Surprisingly, it's not the very young ones who miss home the most, but the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again after dinner, we say it's a bit late to call now, do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and at the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time.

It's not always the children who feel lonely. Sometimes, parents call us a lot, asking how their child is doing, which is not really needed. Often, their son or daughter is busy playing games or doing something else, so we have to tell the parents to call back later.

We often see a certain type of child coming to camp, usually wearing expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we tell them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won ‘Best Musical’ four times! Doing the show with only British actors was difficult. In the UK, young actors can do fewer shows each week than in the USA, so they needed twice as many actors. Luckily, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night because people want to hear the songs that were first popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. ‘It’s great that I get paid to play,’ he said, ‘especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me how busy the young actors are. ‘We have normal school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ And what do they think of the show? ‘Well, my whole class came! The theatre has special ticket prices for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found an extra one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! While the young actors were already musicians, with some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Fortunately, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is really worth seeing.'
